ORDINANCE NO. 19-4-2127
AN ORDINANCE AMENDING SECTION 51.074 OF
THE VILLAGE CODE REGARDING WATER SYSTEMS
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 4/360
VILLAGE OF LINDENHURST
LAKE COUNTY , ILLINOIS
Published in Pamphlet Form by Authority of the
President and Board of Trustees
of the
Village of Lindenhurst, Lake County, Illinois
Date of Publication: April 22, 2019
ORDINANCE NO. 19-4-2127
AN ORDINANCE AMENDING SECTION 51.074 OF
THE VILLAGE CODE REGARDING WATER SYSTEMS
WHEREAS, the Village is authorized by various provisions of the Illinois Municipal Code, 65 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq., to operate a water system, and has incorporated
various regulations pertaining to the operation of the water system into the Village Code; and
WHEREAS, in 2012, the Village Board adopted Ordinance No. 12-4-1888 to amend Section 51.074 of the Village Code to place responsibility on property owners
for repairs to and maintenance of buffalo boxes and curb stops connected to the public water system; and
WHEREAS, the Village Board finds it to be in the best interests of the Village and its residents to amend Section 51.074 of the Village Code to return
responsibility to the Village for repairs to and maintenance of buffalo boxes and curb stops and to address certain CLCJAWA facilities, as set forth in this ordinance;
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED by the President and Board of Trustees of the Village of Lindenhurst, Lake County, Illinois, as follows:
Section 1. Recitals. The recitals are incorporated into this Ordinance by reference.
Section 2. Amendment to Section 51.074. Section 51.047, entitled “Water System,” of the Lindenhurst Village Code is amended as follows (added text is
shown as double-underlined text and deleted text is shown as strikethrough text):
“§ 51.074 WATER SYSTEM.
(A) The water system shall be considered as made up of 2 3 parts: the source facilities, the public water supply system and the consumer's water
system.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 5/360
(B) The source facilities shall include all components of the facilities utilized in the production, treatment, storage, and delivery of water to
the public water supply distribution system.
(C) The public water supply system shall consist of the source facilities and the distribution system, and shall include all those facilities of the potable
water system under the control of the village up to and including the point where the consumer's water system begins. The source facilities shall
include all components of the facilities utilized in the production, treatment, storage, and delivery of water to the public water supply distribution
system.
(D) The public water supply distribution system shall include the network of conduits used to deliver water from the source to the consumer's water
system.The public water supply system shall also consist of the service saddle, piping from the service saddle to the curb stop, buffalo
box, and curb stop.
(E) The consumer's water system begins at the outlet side of the curb stop and shall include all parts of the facilities from the source of the
consumer's water system up to and including the buffalo box and curb stop and all piping to the point of use.
(F) The consumer shall be responsible for all repairs to the consumer's water system. However, the consumer shall only be responsible for repairs to
the buffalo box or curb stop under the following conditions:
(1) Damage or any necessary repairs that may result from the village's attempts to locate, inspect or utilize a buffalo box or curb stop.
(2) Damage or any necessary repairs to the buffalo box or curb stop caused by someone other than the village.
(G) In the event an owner fails to repair a component of the consumer’s water system prior to the metering source buffalo box, curb stop or
water service line within 48 hours from the date the village notifies the owner that such repairs are necessary, the village may perform such repair
work and charge the owner of the premises served for the costs expended. In addition, in the event of an emergency, the village may repair any
service pipes and charge the owner of the premises served for the costs expended.
(H) Any work on the consumer's water system or any work in the public right of way shall require a permit from the village prior to the commencement
of any work.
Payment of the above costs are subject to the penalty, delinquency notice, and service, and a lien against the premises for nonpayment of such
costs shall be served to the same extent and with the same effect as for delinquencies pursuant to § 51.093 of this chapter.”
SECTION 3. Conflict. All Ordinances and parts of Ordinances in conflict with this Ordinance are hereby repealed.
SECTION 4. Effective Date. This Ordinance shall be in full force and effect following its passage and approval as required by law.
PASSED AND APPROVED by the President and Board of Trustees of the Village of Lindenhurst, Illinois, this 22nd day of April, 2019.

ORDINANCE NO. 19-4-2129
AN ORDINANCE ESTABLISHING CERTAIN RATES, FEES, AND CHARGES FOR WATER AND SEWER USE WITHIN THE VILLAGE OF
LINDENHURST
VILLAGE OF LINDENHURST
LAKE COUNTY, ILLINOIS
Published in Pamphlet Form by Authority of the
President and Board of Trustees
of the
Village of Lindenhurst, Lake County, Illinois
Date of Publication: April 22, 2019
ORDINANCE NO. 19-4-2129
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 7/360
AN ORDINANCE ESTABLISHING CERTAIN RATES, FEES, AND CHARGES FOR
WATER AND SEWER USE WITHIN THE VILLAGE OF LINDENHURST
WHEREAS, the Village has adopted in Chapter 51 of the Lindenhurst Village Code certain rates, fees, and charges pertaining to the supply of water and
collection of sanitary sewer; and
WHEREAS, the Village Board has reviewed the charges for the utility funds and associated operational and capital costs as required by ordinance; and;
WHEREAS, the President and Village Board desire to suspend the automatic annual increase for water and sewer use in Chapter 51 for the period of May 1,
2019 and ending April 30, 2020, as set forth in this Ordinance; and
WHEREAS, the President and Village Board also desire to establish and impose a capital utility fee that would be used for CLCJAWA transmission
improvements, distribution system improvements, capital improvements, and debt service to ensure the proper operation of the Village’s utility systems, among other
uses, as set forth in this Ordinance.
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED by the President and Board of Trustees of the Village of Lindenhurst, Lake County, Illinois, that
Section 1. Subsection (C) of Section 51.091, entitled “Rates and Charges Established,” of Chapter 51, entitled “Waterworks and Sewer System,” of
the Lindenhurst Village Code is hereby amended as follows:
(C) Annual Review And Rate Plan Established: Each year, as part of the annual budget process, the Village Board will examine the financial status of the
Water and Sewer Enterprise Fund to determine if the rate plan set forth in this section should be modified. Unless otherwise modified by the Village
Board, the rate plan shall be established in this section and § 51.092 of this chapter. The annual 2% increase to monthly charges is hereby suspended for
the period beginning May 1, 2018 2019 and ending April 30, 2019 2020 or until amended by the Village Board, whichever is first.
Section 2. Section 51.091, entitled “Rates and Charges Established,” of Chapter 51, entitled “Waterworks and Sewer System,” of the Lindenhurst
Village Code is hereby amended to add a new Subsection (D) to that Section, which new Subsection 51.091(D) shall hereafter be and read as follows:
“(D) Capital Utility Fee. In addition to the water service and sewer service charges set forth above in this Section, a capital utility
fee shall be imposed on each utility customer in the amount of $2.25 per month for the period beginning May 1, 2019 and
ending April 30, 2020. The fee will be increased to $4.50 per month for the period beginning May 1, 2020 and ending April 30,
2021, and to $6.75 per month for the period beginning May 1, 2021 and ending April 30, 2022. The capital utility fee is not
subject to the senior citizen discount. The capital utility fee will be billed on a bi-monthly basis on utility customers’ sewer and water
bills.”
Section 3. This Ordinance shall be in full force and effect beginning May 1, 2019.
PASSED AND APPROVED by the President and Board of Trustees of the Village of Lindenhurst, Illinois this 22nd day of April, 2019.

PREFACE
This municipal code of the village of Lindenhurst, as supplemented, contains ordinances up to and including ordinance 18-8-2119, passed August 13,
2018. Ordinances of the village adopted after said ordinance supersede the provisions of this municipal code to the extent that they are in conflict or
inconsistent therewith. Consult the village office in order to ascertain whether any particular provision of the code has been amended, superseded or
repealed.
Sterling Codifiers
Coeur d'Alene, Idaho
ADOPTING ORDINANCE
ORDINANCE NO. 94-4-864
ENACTING AS AN ORDINANCE, A CODE OF ORDINANCES FOR THE VILLAGE OF LINDENHURST, LAKE COUNTY, ILLINOIS, REVISING,
AMENDING, RESTATING, CODIFYING, AND COMPILING CERTAIN EXISTING GENERAL ORDINANCES OF THE VILLAGE DEALING WITH
SUBJECTS EMBRACED IN SAID CODE
WHEREAS, the present general ordinances of the Village of Lindenhurst are incomplete and inadequate and the manner of arrangement, classification
and indexing thereof is insufficient to meet the immediate needs of the Village; and,
WHEREAS, the Acts of the State Legislature of the State of Illinois empower and authorize the Village Board of this Village to revise, amend, restate,
codify and to compile any existing ordinance or ordinances and all new ordinances not heretofore adopted or published and to incorporate said ordinances
into one ordinance in book form; and,
WHEREAS, the Village Board of the Village of Lindenhurst has authorized a general compilation, revision and codification of the ordinances of the Village
of a general and permanent nature and publication of such ordinances in book form.
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED by the President and Board of Trustees of the Village of Lindenhurst, Lake County, Illinois, as follows:
SECTION I: The general ordinances of the Village of Lindenhurst as herein revised, amended, restated, codified, and compiled in book form are adopted
as and shall constitute the Code of Ordinances of the Village of Lindenhurst.
SECTION II: Said Code as adopted in Section I shall consist of the following titles, to-wit:
Title I General Provisions
Title III Administration
Title V Public Works
Title VII Traffic Code
Title IX General Regulations
Title XI Business Regulations
Title XIII General Offenses
Title XV Land Usage
Tables of Special Ordinances
Parallel References
Index
SECTION III: All prior ordinances pertaining to the subjects treated in said Code shall be deemed repealed from and after the effective date of said Code
except as they are included and reordained in whole or in part in said Code; provided such repeal shall not affect any offense committed or penalty
incurred or any right established prior to the effective date of said Code, nor shall such repeal affect the provisions of ordinances levying taxes,
appropriating money, annexing or detaching territory establishing franchises or granting special rights to certain persons, authorizing public improvements,
authorizing the issuance of bonds or borrowing of money, authorizing the purchase or sale of real or personal property, granting or accepting easements,
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 9/360
plat or dedication of land to public use, naming or vacating or setting the boundaries of streets, alleys or other public places, nor to any other ordinance of
a temporary or special nature or pertaining to subjects not contained therein, nor to any other ordinance now in existence inadvertently omitted therefrom.
SECTION IV: Said Code shall be deemed published as of the day of its adoption and approval by the Village Board and the Clerk of the Village of
Lindenhurst is hereby authorized and ordered to file a copy of said Code in the Office of the Village Clerk.
SECTION V: Said Code shall be in full force and effect after its passage, approval and publication as provided by law and filing thereof in the Office of the
Clerk, and said Code shall be presumptive evidence in all courts and places of the ordinance and all provisions, sections, penalties and regulations therein
contained and of the date of passage, and that the same is properly signed, attested, recorded and approved and that any public hearings and notices
thereof as required by law have been given.
PASSED AND ADOPTED by the President and Board of Trustees of the Village of Lindenhurst this 11th day of April, 1994.
Title 1
GENERAL PROVISIONS
Chapter 10
GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 10.01 TITLE OF CODE.
This codification of ordinances by and for the municipality of Lindenhurst shall be designated as the CODE OF LINDENHURST and may be so cited.
(1968 Code, § 1.04)
§ 10.02 INTERPRETATION.
Unless otherwise provided herein, or by law or implication required, the same rules of construction, definition, and application shall govern the
interpretation of this code as those governing the interpretation of state law.
(1968 Code, § 1.04)
§ 10.03 APPLICATION TO FUTURE ORDINANCES.
All provisions of this title compatible with future legislation shall apply to ordinances hereafter adopted amending or supplementing this code unless
otherwise specifically provided.
(1968 Code, § 1.04)
§ 10.04 CAPTIONS.
Headings and captions used in this code other than the title, chapter, and section numbers are employed for reference purposes only and shall not be
deemed a part of the text of any section.
(1968 Code, § 1.04)
§ 10.05 DEFINITIONS.
(A) General Rule: Words and phrases shall be taken in their plain, or ordinary and usual sense. However, technical words and phrases having a peculiar
and appropriate meaning in law shall be understood according to their technical import.
(B) Specific Definitions: For the purpose of this code, the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different
meaning:
CODE, THIS CODE or THIS CODE OF ORDINANCES. This municipal code as modified by amendment, revision, and adoption of new titles, chapters,
or sections.
COUNTY. Lake County, Illinois.
MAY. The act referred to is permissive.
MONTH. A calendar month.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 10/360
OATH. An affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words SWEAR and SWORN
shall be equivalent to the words AFFIRM and AFFIRMED.
OFFICER, OFFICE, EMPLOYEE, COMMISSION, or DEPARTMENT. An officer, office, employee, commission, or department of this municipality
unless the context clearly requires otherwise.
PERSON. Extends to and includes person, persons, firm, corporation, copartnership, trustee, lessee, or receiver. Whenever used in any clause
prescribing and imposing a penalty, the terms PERSON or WHOEVER as applied to any unincorporated entity shall mean the partners or members
thereof and as applied to corporations, the officers or agents thereof.
PRECEDING or FOLLOWING. Next before or next after, respectively.
SHALL. The act referred to is mandatory.
SIGNATURE or SUBSCRIPTION. Includes a mark when the person cannot write.
STATE. The state of Illinois.
SUBCHAPTER. A division of a chapter, designated in this code by a heading in the chapter analysis and a capitalized heading in the body of the
chapter, setting apart a group of sections related by the subject matter of the heading. Not all chapters have subchapters.
VILLAGE, MUNICIPAL CORPORATION, MUNICIPALITY, or TOWN. The village of Lindenhurst, Illinois.
WRITTEN. Any representation of words, letters, or figures, whether by printing or otherwise.
YEAR. A calendar year, unless otherwise expressed; equivalent to the words YEAR OF OUR LORD.
(1968 Code, § 1.04)
§ 10.06 RULES OF INTERPRETATION.
The construction of all ordinances of this municipality shall be by the following rules, unless the construction is plainly repugnant to the intent of the
legislative body or of the context of the same ordinance:
(A) And Or Or: Either conjunction shall include the other as if written "and/or", if the sense requires it.
(B) Acts By Assistants: When a statute or ordinance requires an act to be done which, by law, an agent or deputy as well may do as the principal, the
requisition shall be satisfied by the performance of the act by an authorized agent or deputy.
(C) Gender; Singular And Plural; Tenses: Words denoting the masculine gender shall be deemed to include the feminine and neuter genders; words in the
singular shall include the plural and words in the plural shall include the singular; the use of a verb in the present tense shall include the future, if
applicable.
(D) General Term: A general term following specific enumeration of terms is not to be limited to the class enumerated unless expressly so limited.
(1968 Code, § 1.04)
§ 10.07 SEVERABILITY.
If any provision of this code as now or later amended or its application to any person or circumstance is held invalid, the invalidity does not affect other
provisions that can be given effect without the invalid provision or application.
(1968 Code, § 1.04)
§ 10.08 REFERENCE TO OTHER SECTIONS.
Whenever in one section reference is made to another section hereof, the reference shall extend and apply to the section referred to as subsequently
amended, revised, recodified, or renumbered unless the subject matter is changed or materially altered by the amendment or revision.
(1968 Code, § 1.04)
§ 10.09 REFERENCE TO OFFICES.
Reference to a public office or officer shall be deemed to apply to any office, officer, or employee of this municipality exercising the powers, duties, or
functions contemplated in the provision, irrespective of any transfer of functions or change in the official title of the functionary.
(1968 Code, § 1.04)
§ 10.10 ERRORS AND OMISSIONS.
If a manifest error is discovered, consisting of the misspelling of any words; the omission of any word or words necessary to express the intention of the
provisions affected; the use of a word or words to which no meaning can be attached; or the use of a word or words when another word or words was
clearly intended to express the intent, the spelling shall be corrected and such word or words supplied, omitted, or substituted as will conform with the
manifest intention, and the provisions shall have the same effect as though the correct words were contained in the text as originally published. No
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 11/360
alteration shall be made or permitted if any question exists regarding the nature or extent of the error.
(1968 Code, § 1.04)
§ 10.11 OFFICIAL TIME.
The official time, as established by applicable state/federal laws, shall be the official time within this municipality for the transaction of all municipal
business.
(1968 Code, § 1.04)
§ 10.12 REASONABLE TIME.
(A) In all cases where an ordinance requires an act to be done in a reasonable time or requires reasonable notice to be given, reasonable time or notice
shall be deemed to mean the time which is necessary for a prompt performance of the act or the giving of the notice.
(B) The time within which an act is to be done, as herein provided, shall be computed by excluding the first day and including the last. If the last day be
Sunday, it shall be excluded.
(1968 Code, § 1.04)
§ 10.13 ORDINANCES REPEALED.
This code, from and after its effective date, shall contain all of the provisions of a general nature pertaining to the subjects herein enumerated and
embraced. All prior ordinances pertaining to the subjects treated by this code shall be deemed repealed from and after the effective date of this code.
(1968 Code, § 1.04)
§ 10.14 ORDINANCES UNAFFECTED.
All ordinances of a temporary or special nature and all other ordinances pertaining to subjects not embraced in this code shall remain in full force and
effect unless herein repealed expressly or by necessary implication.
(1968 Code, § 1.04)
§ 10.15 EFFECTIVE DATE OF ORDINANCES.
All ordinances passed by the legislative body requiring publication shall take effect from and after the due publication thereof, unless otherwise expressly
provided. Ordinances not requiring publication shall take effect from their passage, unless otherwise expressly provided.
(1968 Code, § 1.04)
§ 10.16 REPEAL OR MODIFICATION OF ORDINANCE.
(A) Whenever any ordinance or part of an ordinance shall be repealed or modified by a subsequent ordinance, the ordinance or part of an ordinance thus
repealed or modified shall continue in force until the due publication of the ordinance repealing or modifying it when publication is required to give effect
thereto, unless otherwise expressly provided.
(B) No suit, proceedings, right, fine, forfeiture, or penalty instituted, created, given, secured, or accrued under any ordinance previous to its repeal shall in
anywise be effected, released, or discharged, but may be prosecuted, enjoyed, and recovered as fully as if the ordinance had continued in force unless
it is otherwise expressly provided.
(C) When any ordinance repealing a former ordinance, clause, or provision shall by itself be repealed, the repeal shall not be construed to revive the
former ordinance, clause, or provision, unless it is expressly provided.
(1968 Code, § 1.04)
§ 10.17 ORDINANCES WHICH AMEND OR SUPPLEMENT CODE.
(A) If the legislative body shall desire to amend any existing chapter or section of this code, the chapter or section shall be specifically repealed and a new
chapter or section, containing the desired amendment, substituted in its place.
(B) Any ordinance which is proposed to add to the existing code a new chapter or section shall indicate, with reference to the arrangement of this code, the
proper number of the chapter or section. In addition to the indication thereof as may appear in the text of the proposed ordinance, a caption or title shall
be shown in concise form above the ordinance.
(1968 Code, § 1.04)
§ 10.18 SECTION HISTORIES; STATUTORY REFERENCES.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 12/360
(A) As histories for the code sections, the specific number and passage date of the original ordinance, and the most recent 3 amending ordinances, if any,
are listed following the text of the code section. Example: (Ord. 10, passed 5-13-60; Am. Ord. 15, passed 1-1-70; Am. Ord. 20, passed 1-1-80; Am.
Ord. 25, passed 1-1-85)
(B) (1) If a statutory cite is included in the history, this indicates that the text of the section reads substantially the same as the statute. Example: (ILCS Ch.
65, Act 5, § 3.1-5-5) (Ord. 10, passed 1-17-80; Am. Ord. 20, passed 1-1-85)
(2) If a statutory cite is set forth as a "statutory reference" following the text of the section, this indicates that the reader should refer to that statute for
further information.
Example:
§ 31.10 MAYOR.
The Mayor shall hold office for 4 years.
(Ord. 10, passed 1-1-80)
Statutory reference:
For term of the Mayor, see ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 3.1-15-10
(1968 Code, § 1.04)
§ 10.19 JURISDICTION.
Unless otherwise provided in this code, this code shall apply to all acts performed within the corporate limits of the village. Provisions of this code shall
also apply to acts performed outside the corporate limits and up to the limits provided by law, where the law confers power on the village to regulate the
particular acts outside the corporate limits.
(1968 Code, § 1.04)
§ 10.20 PROSECUTING OFFICER MAY ELECT UNDER WHICH SECTION TO PROSECUTE.
In all cases, when the same offense may be punishable, or be cognizable by different clauses or sections of the ordinances, the prosecuting officer may
elect under which to proceed; but no more than 1 recovery may be had against the same person for the same offense.
(1968 Code, § 1.09)
§ 10.21 CUSTODY AND DISTRIBUTION OF MUNICIPAL CODE.
All the printed books containing this code shall be deposited with the village clerk. He shall deliver 1 copy thereof to each officer of the village and to such
other persons as the board of trustees may direct. The president or board of trustees shall have the power to extend or to reciprocate courtesies of other
municipal corporations by presenting to them a copy of the general ordinances, bound at the expense of the village, in such manner as to him may seem
suitable. Copies of the municipal code shall be offered for sale by the village clerk at the amount per copy as is established by the village.
(1968 Code, § 1.12)
§ 10.22 DEVELOPMENT FEES.
(A) Escrow Required: Any person, corporation or partnership which desires to annex property to, rezone property within, request a special use from,
request architectural review from or request a variance from the village of Lindenhurst must post with the village a cash escrow sufficient in size as
determined by the village administrator, to cover any and all village attorney fees, village planning fees and other outside consulting fees necessitated
by the requested action. As funds from said escrow are used to pay the covered fees, the escrowee must reestablish the initial escrow amount as billed
monthly by the village.
(B) Administrative Fees: Whenever any escrow is established pursuant to division (A) of this section, the village shall be entitled to deduct from the escrow
the sum of 31/2% of any sums paid out by the village from said escrow as an administrative fee for the handling of said funds.
(Ord. 99-1-1118, passed 1-25-1999; Am. Ord. 99-8-1148, passed 8-23-1999)
§ 10.23 CHARGES FOR NSF CHECKS, NSF AUTOMATIC ACCOUNT WITHDRAWALS, CREDIT OR DEBIT CARD REJECTIONS
OR REJECTION OF ANY NONCASH PAYMENT.
Any person, corporation or partnership which issues any check, authorizes any credit card, debit card or automatic withdrawal transaction or any other
noncash payment in payment of any village bill, fee, fine or penalty which is not honored or is rejected by the involved financial institution shall owe to the
village in addition to the amount due a charge in the amount of $30.
(Ord. 05-2-1443, passed 2-14-2005)
§ 10.99 GENERAL PENALTY.
Any person, firm, or corporation who violates any provisions of this code for which another penalty is not specifically provided shall, upon conviction, be
subject to a fine of not less than $50 and not exceeding $750. Each day upon which a violation occurs or continues shall be deemed a separate offense.
(Ord. 91-9-789, passed 9-23-1991, eff. 10-1-1991; Am. Ord. 96-4-975, passed 4-22-1996)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 13/360
Chapter 11
CORPORATE SEAL
§ 11.01 CORPORATE SEAL.
The corporate seal of the village shall be as follows: a circular disc with the words "VILLAGE OF LINDENHURST, LAKE COUNTY, ILL." on the periphery
thereof, and "VILLAGE CLERK CORPORATE SEAL" in the center.
('68 Code, § 7.04(a))
Title 3
ADMINISTRATION
Chapter 30
BOARD OF TRUSTEES
General Provisions
§ 30.01 ELECTIONS; FUNCTIONS.
(A) The board of trustees, consisting of 6 members, shall be elected to office for a term of 4 years as provided by statute. The board shall be the legislative
department of the village government and shall perform such duties and have such powers as may be delegated to it by statute.
(B) The village president shall be elected for a term of 4 years and shall serve until his successor is elected and qualified as provided by statute. He may
be referred to as the mayor of the village.
(1968 Code, § 3.01) (Ord. 76-0-318, passed 6-14-1976; Am. Ord. 77-0-337, passed 5-9-1977)
§ 30.02 OATH; SALARY.
The members of the board of trustees shall take the oath of office prescribed by statute and shall receive compensation as may, from time to time, be
provided by ordinance.
(1968 Code, § 3.02) (Ord. 65-0-99, passed 11- -1965)
§ 30.03 MEETINGS.
(A) The regular meetings of the board of trustees shall be held on the second and fourth Monday of each month of the year at 7:00 p.m. and no notice of
the regular meetings shall be required except for posting of the requisite notice of the holding of such meetings pursuant to the open meetings act of
the state of Illinois1. If any regular meeting falls on a legal holiday, the meeting shall take place on the next Monday at the same hour and place.
Adjourned meetings shall be held at such other times as the board may determine.
(B) The meeting place of the said board shall be at the village hall unless otherwise ordered by the board.
(C) Special meetings may be called by the village president or any 3 trustees upon at least 48 hours' notice to all members of the board of trustees and the
village president. Notice of special meetings shall be as required in the open meetings act2.
(1968 Code, § 3.03) (Ord. 65-0-111, passed 7-6-1965; Am. Ord. 74-0-263, passed 7-8-1974; Am. Ord. 96-9-991, passed 9-23-1996)
§ 30.04 RECORD OF ORDINANCES.
All ordinances passed by the board of trustees shall be consecutively numbered and recorded by the village clerk in a proper book or books with indexes.
The original shall be filed in the office of the clerk and due proof of publication of all ordinances requiring publication shall be procured by the clerk, and the
proof or affidavit of publications shall be attached to and filed with the ordinances. The clerk also shall note on his book of ordinances, at the foot of the
record of each ordinance, a memorandum of the date of the passage, and if published or posted, of the date of the publication or posting of the ordinance.
(1968 Code, § 1.11)
Rules Of Order
§ 30.15 QUORUM.
A majority of the trustees, or the president and 3 trustees, shall constitute a quorum to do business. A smaller number, however, may adjourn from time to
time and may compel the attendance of absentees under penalties (including a fine for a failure to attend) prescribed by the trustees by ordinance3.
(1968 Code, § 3.04) (Ord. 61-0-66, passed 8-14-1961)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 14/360
§ 30.16 STANDING COMMITTEES.
The following shall be the standing committees of the board of trustees:
Committee on finance
Committee on human resources
(1968 Code, § 3.05) (Ord. 75-0-294, passed - -1975; Am. Ord. 90-7-743, passed 7-9-1990; Am. Ord. 91-6-781, passed 6-10-1991; Am. Ord. 01-7-1246,
passed 7-9-2001; Am. Ord. 03-5-1323, passed 5-19-2003)
§ 30.17 SPECIAL COMMITTEES.
The president shall appoint such special committees as he may deem necessary or as may be directed by the board of trustees.
(1968 Code, § 3.06)
§ 30.18 MEMBERSHIP ON COMMITTEES.
The president shall appoint the members of all standing and special committees in the absence of specific direction by the board of trustees and shall
designate the chairmen thereof. Every committee of the board of trustees shall consist of 3 members, including the chairman, unless the board directs
otherwise.
(1968 Code, § 3.07)
§ 30.19 ORDER OF BUSINESS.
The order of business at meetings of the board of trustees shall be as follows:
(A) Roll call.
(B) Approval of minutes of previous meeting(s).
(C) Report of the village treasurer.
(D) Reading and approval of bills against the village.
(E) Reports of village officers other than the village treasurer.
(F) Reports of standing committees.
(G) Reports of special committees.
(H) Unfinished business.
(I) Presentation of communications or petitions.
(J) New business.
(1968 Code, § 3.08) (Ord. 65-0-111, passed 7-6-1965)
§ 30.20 RESCINDING ACTION.
No vote or action of the board of trustees shall be rescinded at any special meeting unless there be present at such special meeting as many members of
the board as were present at the meeting when such vote or action was taken, as is provided by statute.
(1968 Code, § 3.09)
§ 30.21 RESOLUTIONS.
Any resolution submitted to the board of trustees shall be reduced to writing before being voted upon at the request of any 2 members of the board.
(1968 Code, § 3.10)
§ 30.22 ADDRESSING MEETINGS.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 15/360
(A) Public Comment Policy: Pursuant to and in accordance with section 2.06(g) of the Illinois Open Meetings Act, the Board of Trustees will provide 2
separate opportunities for public comment at Board meetings. The first opportunity is during the "public comment - agenda items" agenda item that is
scheduled before the business portion of the Board meeting. The second opportunity for public comment is during "public comment - general items"
agenda item that is scheduled at the conclusion of the business portion of the Board meeting.
The Board has a responsibility to conduct the business of the Village in an orderly and efficient manner and to establish reasonable procedures for
public comment at its meetings. The Mayor, as Chair of the meeting (or the Chair Pro-Tem in the Mayor's absence) is responsible for ensuring the
orderly conduct of the meeting and will rule on the appropriateness of any public comment issues that may arise.
The following procedures for public comment are intended to maintain the orderly conduct of meetings and ensure fairness to those who wish to
address the Board:
(1) Anyone interested in speaking publicly at a Board meeting is welcome. Individuals are asked to sign in just prior to the start of the meeting.
(2) Speakers will be limited to 3 minutes per person during either public comment portion of the meeting. The total time allotted for the public comment
periods will be 30 minutes, unless a majority of the Board votes to extend the discussion.
(3) Any person who is not allowed to make remarks during public comment shall be permitted to submit written comment to the Board either before or
after the time for public comment with the Village Clerk.
(4) Only 1 person may speak at a time during any public comment period.
(5) No person may assign their time to any other person.
(6) The Chair may deny a person who has previously addressed the Board the opportunity to speak again during the same meeting on the same topic.
(7) No person may address the Board or engage in public comment except during 1 of the 2 defined public comment periods, when recognized by the
Chair.
(8) During any public comment period, Board members may ask questions of the speaker while he or she is speaking, if recognized by the Chair.
However, the Board need not answer questions from a speaker during any public comment period. If a person has a question for the Board, the
individual may be asked to submit the question in writing.
(9) All comments must be civil in nature. Any person who engages in threatening, slanderous, or disorderly behavior when addressing the Board, or
who speaks out of turn or otherwise disrupts the Board meeting, shall be deemed out-of-order by the Chair. Repeated or extraordinary occurrences
of disorderly conduct shall be grounds for the Chair to cause the violator to be removed from the meeting room. The Chair will rule on whether
remarks made are in violation of this policy.
(10) The Board has the authority to determine procedural matters regarding public participation not otherwise defined in this policy and not inconsistent
with this policy.
(B) Public Hearings: All public hearings required by State Statute to be held by the Board of Trustees will be conducted in accordance with State Statute.
All persons offering testimony at a hearing shall testify under oath. Public hearings are not part of the public comment period or periods of a meeting
and are not subject to the public comment policy referenced in division (A) of this section.
(1968 Code § 3.11) (Ord. 17-5-2075, passed 5-8-2017)
§ 30.23 SUSPENSION OF RULES.
The rules of order, other than those prescribed by statute, may be suspended at any time by the consent of a majority of the members present at any
meeting.
(1968 Code, § 3.12)
§ 30.24 VOTING.
The President shall vote:
(A) Where the vote of the Trustees has resulted in a tie; or
(B) Where 1/2 of the Trustees elected have voted in favor of an ordinance, resolution or motion even though there is no tie vote; or
(C) Where a vote greater than a majority of the Board is required by statute to adopt an ordinance, resolution or motion. The passage of all ordinances for
whatever purpose, and any resolution or motion to create any liability against the Village or for the expenditure or appropriation of money, shall require
the concurrence of the majority of all members elected to the Board of Trustees, including the President, unless otherwise expressly provided by
statute.
(1968 Code § 3.13)
§ 30.25 ROBERT'S RULES OF ORDER.
The most recently revised sets of Robert's Rules of Order shall govern the deliberations of the Board of Trustees except when in conflict with any of the
foregoing rules.
(1968 Code, § 3.14)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 16/360
Footnote 1: 5 ILCS 120/1.01.
Footnote 2: 5 ILCS 120/2.02.
Footnote 3: 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-20.
Chapter 31
VILLAGE OFFICIALS AND EMPLOYEES
General Provisions
§ 31.001 APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS.
The provisions of this chapter shall apply alike to all officers of the village, regardless of the time of the creation of the office or of the time of the
appointment of the officer.
(1968 Code § 7.01)
§ 31.002 APPOINTMENTS.
The president shall make appointments to fill all appointive offices by and with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. The appointments shall be
suggested by the president for each fiscal year not later than at the June meeting.
(1968 Code § 7.01)
§ 31.003 TERM OF OFFICE.
Every appointive officer or employee of the village shall hold office for the term of 1 year or until his successor is appointed and qualified unless it is
otherwise provided by ordinance.
(1968 Code § 7.01)
§ 31.004 ASSIGNMENT OF DUTIES.
The village president shall have the power to assign to any officer any duty which is not assigned by ordinance to some other specific officer and he shall
determine disputes or questions relating to the respective powers or duties of officers after consultation with the village attorney.
(1968 Code § 7.01)
§ 31.005 RECORDS.
All records kept by any officer of the village shall be open to inspection by the president or any member of the board of trustees at all reasonable times,
whether or not such records are to be kept by statute or ordinance.
(1968 Code § 7.01)
§ 31.006 MONEY RECEIVED.
Every officer of the village shall at least once each month turn over all money received by him in his official capacity to the village clerk with a statement
showing the source from which the same was received.
(1968 Code § 7.01)
§ 31.007 OATH.
Every officer of the village shall, before entering upon his duties, take the oath prescribed by statute.
(1968 Code § 7.01)
§ 31.008 BOND.
Every officer, if required by the board of trustees, before entering upon the duties of his office, shall give a bond in such amount as may be determined by
the board of trustees and with the sureties as it may approve, conditioned upon the faithful performance of the duties of his office or position.
(1968 Code § 7.01)
§ 31.009 SALARIES.
All officers and employees of the village shall receive such salary as may be provided from time to time by ordinance.
(1968 Code § 7.01)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 17/360
§ 31.010 ARRESTS.
The village president, members of the board of trustees, and police officers are hereby declared to be conservators of the peace with such powers to make
arrests as are given to the conservators of the peace by statute.
(1968 Code § 7.01)
§ 31.011 TERMINATION OF OFFICE.
Every officer of the village, upon termination of his office for any cause whatsoever, shall deliver to his successor all books and records which may be the
property of the village; if no successor has been appointed within 1 week after termination of office the property shall be delivered either to the clerk or the
treasurer.
(1968 Code § 7.01)
§ 31.012 ELECTIONS.
Elections for village officers shall be held as is provided by statutes and at the time prescribed by statute.
(1968 Code § 7.04)
§ 31.013 ETHICAL PROCEDURES.
(A) Adoption Of Act:
(1) The regulations of section 5-151 and article 102 of the state officials and employees ethics act, 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/1-1 et seq.
(hereinafter referred to as the "act" in this section), are hereby adopted by reference and made applicable to the officers and employees of the village
to the extent required by 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/70-5.
(2) This section does not repeal or otherwise amend or modify any existing ordinances or policies which regulate the conduct of village officers and
employees. To the extent that any such existing ordinances or policies are less restrictive than this section, however, the provisions of this section
shall prevail in accordance with the provisions of 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/70-5(a).
(B) Prohibitions:
(1) The solicitation or acceptance of gifts prohibited to be solicited or accepted under the act, by any officer or any employee of the village, is hereby
prohibited.
(2) The offering or making of gifts prohibited to be offered or made to an officer or employee of the village under the act, is hereby prohibited.
(3) The participation in political activities prohibited under the act, by any officer or employee of the village is hereby prohibited.
(4) For purposes of this section, the terms "officer" and "employee" shall be defined as set forth in 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/70-5(c).
(C) Penalties: The penalties for violations of this section shall be the same as those penalties set forth in 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/50-5 for similar
violations of the act.
(D) Future Amendments To The Act: Any amendment to the act that becomes effective after the effective date of this section shall be incorporated into this
section by reference and shall be applicable to the solicitation, acceptance, offering and making of gifts and to prohibited political activities. However,
any amendment that makes its provisions optional for adoption by municipalities shall not be incorporated into this section by reference without formal
action by the corporate authorities of the village.
(E) Future Declaration Of Unconstitutionality Of Act:
(1) If the Illinois supreme court declares the act unconstitutional in its entirety, then this section shall be repealed as of the date that the Illinois supreme
court's decision becomes final and not subject to any further appeals or rehearings. This section shall be deemed repealed without further action by
the corporate authorities of the village if the act is found unconstitutional by the Illinois supreme court.
(2) If the Illinois supreme court declares part of the act unconstitutional but upholds the constitutionality of the remainder of the act, or does not address
the remainder of the act, then the remainder of the act as adopted by this section shall remain in full force and effect; however, that part of this
section relating to the part of the act found unconstitutional shall be deemed repealed without further action by the corporate authorities of the village.
(Ord. 99-6-1138, passed 6-14-1999; Am. Ord. 04-5-1393, passed 5-10-2004)
Appointed Officials
§ 31.025 APPOINTMENT OF OFFICERS.
The president shall appoint, by and with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, all officers of the village whose appointment or election is not
otherwise provided for. Any vacancies occurring in appointive offices shall be filled in the same manner. The president shall submit all appointments to the
board of trustees for each year not later than the June meeting.
(1968 Code § 2.03)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 18/360
§ 31.026 DESIGNATION OF OFFICERS' DUTIES.
Whenever there is a dispute as to the respective duties or powers of any appointive officer of the village, this dispute shall be settled by the president after
consultation with the village attorney; the president shall have the power to delegate to any officer any duty which is to be performed when no specific
officer has been directed to perform that duty.
(1968 Code § 2.04)
Village President
§ 31.040 ELECTION AND TERM OF OFFICE.
The village president shall be elected for a term of 4 years and shall serve until his successor is elected and qualified as is provided by statute. He may be
referred to as the mayor of the village.
(1968 Code § 2.01) (Ord. 76-0-318, passed 6-14-1976; Am. Ord. 77-0-337, passed 5-9-1977)
§ 31.041DUTIES.
The village president shall be the chief executive officer of the village and shall preside at all meetings of the board of trustees. He shall perform all such
duties as may be required of him by statute or ordinance. He shall have supervision over all the executive officers and employees of the village and shall
have the power and authority to inspect all books and records pertaining to village affairs and kept by any officer or employee of the village, at any
reasonable time.
(1968 Code § 2.02)
§ 31.042 BOND; OATH; SALARY.
Before entering upon the duties of this office the president shall give a bond with sureties to be approved by the board of trustees conditioned upon the
faithful performance for the duties of his office, in the sum of $3,000. He shall take the oath of office prescribed by statute and shall receive such
compensation as may be set from time to time by the board of trustees.
(1968 Code § 2.05) (Ord. 65-0-98, passed 11- -1965)
Village Administrator
§ 31.055 CREATION OF OFFICE; APPOINTMENT.
There is hereby created the office of village administrator for the village. The village administrator shall be appointed by the village president with the
advice and consent of the village board for a term not to exceed the term of the village president. (For the purposes of definition the "village board" is
defined as consisting of the president and board of trustees.) He shall be chosen for his executive and administrative qualifications with special reference
to his actual experience in or his knowledge of accepted practice in respect to the duties of his office hereinafter set forth. At the time of his appointment he
need not be a resident of the village, but during his tenure of office he shall reside within the village. No board member shall receive such appointment
while he is serving in that capacity. The village administrator shall receive such compensation as the village board shall fix from time to time by ordinance
or resolution.
(Ord. 81-6-474, passed 6-22-1981; Am. Ord. 85-2-568, passed 2-25-1985)
§ 31.056 REMOVAL.
The village administrator shall be subject to removal from office during the term of his appointment as provided in 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3.1-35-
10. If he is terminated by the village for any reason other than removal pursuant to 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3.1-35-10, he shall be paid a sum of
money equal to his then current salary for a 90 day period plus an amount of money necessary to keep his insurance benefits in existence for 90 days
subsequent to his termination. This sum shall be reduced by any deductions required by law.
(Ord. 81-6-474, passed 6-22-1981; Am. Ord. 85-2-568, passed 2-25-1985)
§ 31.057 GENERAL DUTIES.
The village administrator shall be the chief administrative officer of the village, under the direction of the village president, who is the chief executive officer.
He may head 1 or more departments and shall be responsible to the village president and the village board of trustees for the proper administration of all
affairs of the village, excepting, however, the affairs or matters as the president and board of trustees may from time to time determine shall be under their
direct control and supervision. All provisions herein contained shall be subject to the exceptions set forth in the immediately preceding sentence. To the
ends hereinbefore contemplated, but subject to the exceptions and qualifications hereinbefore set forth, the village administrator shall have power and
shall be required to:
(A) Appoint, and when necessary for the good of the service, suspend or remove any employee of the village, excepting any enumerated below, provided
further, that he may authorize the head of a department or office under his control to appoint, suspend, or remove subordinates in such department or
office.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 19/360
(B) Recommend to the president and board of trustees the appointment, suspension or removal of the following officers, employees and persons retained
for services to the village: village attorney, treasurer, chief of police, building commissioner, coordinator of the emergency management agency and any
others which are by village ordinance or other applicable provision to be appointed by the village president with the advice and consent of the board of
trustees.
(C) Prepare the budget annually and submit it to the village board together with a message describing the important features and be responsible for its
administration after adoption.
(D) Furnish to the village board as of the end of the fiscal year a complete report of the finances and administrative activities of the village for the preceding
year.
(E) Keep the village board advised of the financial condition and future needs of the village, and make such recommendations as he may deem desirable.
(F) Recommend to the village board a standard schedule of pay for each appointive office and position in the village service, including minimum,
intermediate and maximum rates.
(G) Recommend to the village board, from time to time, adoption of such measures as he may deem necessary or expedient for the health, safety or
welfare of the community or for the improvement of administrative services.
(H) Recommend to the board of trustees the creating, consolidating and combining of offices, positions, departments or units of the administrative and
executive departments of the village.
(I) Attend all meetings of the village board unless excused therefrom and take part in the discussion of all matters coming before the board. He shall be
entitled to notice of all regular and special meetings of the board.
(J) Supervise the purchase of all materials, supplies and equipment and enter into contracts necessary for the operation or maintenance of village services
as specified in chapter 35 of this title.
(K) See that all laws and ordinances are duly enforced.
(L) Investigate the affairs of any department or division under his jurisdiction, all complaints in relation to matters under his jurisdiction concerning the
administration of the government of the village and in regard to service maintained by the public utilities in the village, and see that all franchises,
permits, and privileges granted by the village are faithfully observed.
(M) Devote his entire time to the discharge of his official duties.
(N) Perform such other duties as may be required by the village board, not inconsistent with this code.
(O) Adhere to the procedures specified in chapter 35 of this title in cases of accident, disaster or other circumstance creating a public emergency.
(P) The village administrator shall furnish a surety bond in the amount of $50,000 to ensure the faithful performance of his duties. The premium for the
bond shall be paid by the village.
(Ord. 81-6-474, passed 6-22-1981; Am. Ord. 85-2-568, passed 2-25-1985; Am. Ord. 92-11-828, passed 11-9-1992; Am. Ord. 05-9-1499, passed 9-26-
2005; Am. Ord. 09-9-1776, passed 9-14-2009)
Village Clerk
§ 31.070 ELECTION AND TERM.
The village clerk shall be elected and serve for a term of 4 years, and until his or her successor is elected and qualified, as is provided by statute.
(1968 Code § 4.01) (Ord. 76-0-318, passed - - ; Am. Ord. 77-0-337, passed 5-9-1977)
§ 31.071 BOND.
Before entering upon the duties of his office the village clerk shall execute a bond in such amount and with such sureties as may be required by the board
of trustees, conditioned upon the faithful performance of his duties.
(1968 Code § 4.02)
§ 31.072 OATH; SALARY.
The village clerk shall take an oath of office as prescribed by statute and shall receive such compensation as may from time to time be provided by
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 20/360
ordinance.
(1968 Code § 4.03)
§ 31.073 SIGNATURES.
The village clerk shall seal and attest all contracts of the village and all licenses, permits and other documents as shall require this formality.
(1968 Code § 4.04)
§ 31.074 RECEIPTS, ACCOUNTS AND RECORDS.
(A) Money Collected: The village clerk shall turn over all money received by him on behalf of the village at the end of each month, to the village treasurer
and with such money he shall give a statement as to the source thereof.
(B) Accounts: The village clerk shall keep accounts showing all money received by him and the source and disposition thereof; and other accounts as may
be required by statute or ordinance.
(C) Records: In addition to the record of ordinances and other records which the village clerk is required by statute to keep, the clerk shall keep a register
of all licenses and permits issued, and the payments thereon; a record showing all of the officers and regular employees of the village; and such other
records as may be required by the board of trustees.
(1968 Code §§ 4.05, 4.06, 4.07)
§ 31.075 SEAL.
The village clerk shall be the custodian of the village seal, and shall affix its impression on documents whenever this is required.
(1968 Code § 4.08)
§ 31.076 DOCUMENTS.
The village clerk shall be the custodian of the village seal, and shall affix its impression on documents whenever this is required.
(1968 Code § 4.09)
§ 31.077 INDICES.
The village clerk shall keep and maintain a proper index to all documents and records kept by him, so that ready access thereto and use thereof may be
had.
(1968 Code § 4.10)
§ 31.078 ADDITIONAL DUTIES.
In addition to the duties herein provided the village clerk shall perform other duties and functions as may be required by statute or ordinance. He shall act
as village collector unless and until a separate village collector is appointed as provided by law. (1968 Code § 4.11)
§ 31.079 DEPUTY CLERK.
(A) There is hereby created the office of deputy clerk in and for the village. The village clerk is hereby authorized to appoint 1 or more deputy clerks with
the advice and consent of the village board of trustees as shall be needed to efficiently run the office of village clerk.
(B) The deputy clerk shall have the power and duty to execute all documents required by law to be executed by the village clerk and to affix the seal of the
village thereto when required. In signing any documents the deputy clerk shall sign the name of the village clerk followed by the word "By" and the
deputy clerk's own name and the words "Deputy Clerk". The deputy clerk shall act only in the absence of the village clerk from the village hall and only
upon written direction when it has been given by the village clerk or when the board of trustees shall have determined by resolution that the village
clerk is temporarily or permanently incapacitated to perform his powers and duties.
(C) The term of office for the deputy clerk shall be for a period of up to 1 year, ending on April 30 subsequent to his or her appointment. The deputy clerk
shall serve without pay.
(1968 Code §§ 4.12, 4.13) (Ord. 58-0-38, passed 12- -1958; Am. Ord. 76-0-318, passed - - ; Am. Ord. 92-1-799, passed 1-13-1992)
Village Attorney
§ 31.090 CREATION OF OFFICE; APPOINTMENT.
There is created the office of village attorney, an executive office of the village. The attorney shall be appointed by the president by and with the advice and
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 21/360
consent of the board of trustees.
(1968 Code § 5.01)
§ 31.091 LEGAL ADVISER.
The attorney shall be the legal adviser of the village and shall render advice on all legal questions affecting the village whenever requested to do so by the
village president or any member of the board of trustees. Upon request by the president or the board of trustees he shall reduce any such opinion to
writing and upon request by the board he shall render an opinion to any officer of the village with regard to his duties or powers.
(1968 Code § 5.01)
§ 31.092 DUTIES.
(A) The attorney shall prosecute or defend any and all suits or actions at law or equity to which the village may be a party or in which it may be interested
or which may be brought against or by any officer of the village on the behalf of the municipality or in the capacity of such person as an officer of the
village, whenever directed to so do by the board.
(B) It shall be the duty of the attorney to see to the full enforcement of all judgments of decrees rendered or entered in favor of the village, and of all similar
interlocutory orders.
(C) It shall be the duty of the attorney to see to the completion of all special assessment proceedings and condemnation proceedings.
(D) It shall be the duty of the attorney to draft or supervise the phraseology of any contracts, leases or other documents or instruments to which the village
may be a party and upon request by the board of trustees to draft ordinances covering any subjects within the powers of the village.
(1968 Code § 5.01)
Village Collector
§ 31.105 CREATION OF OFFICE; APPOINTMENT.
There is hereby established and created the office of village collector, and the person holding such office shall be the head of the village collection
department and designated as the village collector. The village collector shall be appointed by the mayor by and with the consent of the village board of
trustees, having a term of 1 year.
(Ord. 71-0-185, passed 4-12-1971)
§ 31.106 COMPENSATION.
The compensation to be paid to the village collector shall be that amount which will be established from time to time by the mayor by and with the consent
of the village board of trustees.
(Ord. 71-0-184, passed 4-12-1971)
§ 31.107 APPOINTMENT OF VILLAGE CLERK AS VILLAGE COLLECTOR.
At the discretion of the mayor and members of the board of trustees, the village clerk may be appointed to hold the office of village collector.
(Ord. 71-0-184, passed 4-12-1971; Am. Ord. 85-7-575, passed 7-22-1985)
§ 31.108 COLLECTOR'S DUTIES.
(A) The village collector shall keep such books and accounts in the manner as the village president and members of the village board of trustees may
prescribe. The books and all papers pertaining to the collector's office shall at all times be open to inspection of and subject to examination of the
mayor, clerk or any member of the village board of trustees or committee thereof.
(B) The village collector monthly shall pay to the treasurer all money collected from any source whatsoever and take receipt therefor.
(C) The village collector shall make a report in writing to the village board of trustees, or any officer designated by the board of trustees, on the second
Monday of every month, of all money collected by said village collector, the account whereon collected, or of any other matter in connection with said
office of village collector when required by the board of trustees or by any ordinance of the village. Also, the village collector, annually between April 1
and April 10, shall make a report to the village board of trustees of all the money collected during the preceding year, the particular warrant, special
assessment or account on which collected, the balance of money uncollected on all warrants and the balance remaining uncollected at the time of the
returnable warrants which said village collector shall have returned during the preceding fiscal year to the village clerk. The village clerk shall publish
the same as required by law.
(D) The village collector is expressly prohibited from keeping the money of the village in his or her hands or in the hands of any person or corporation for
his or her use beyond the time which may be prescribed for the payment of the same to the treasurer; any violation of this provision will subject the
village collector to immediate removal from office.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 22/360
(E) The village collector shall receive all applications for license, fees for license, inspections and permits, including fees for building and engineering
permits, and all other fees that may be authorized by the village board of trustees for collection; also compensation for franchises, collection of special
assessments when authorized by the board of trustees, special taxes and taxes in the nature of special assessments, and all other payments of money
not otherwise specifically provided for.
(F) The village collector is authorized to receive the collection of all fines to be paid over to the village relating to the violation of any village ordinance,
where fees or collections are involved on behalf of the village.
(G) The village collector shall perform other duties as may be prescribed for his office by statute or by ordinance.
(Ord. 71-0-184, passed 4-12-1971; Am. Ord. 76-0-318, passed 6-14-1976)
§ 31.109 BOND.
The village collector shall give bond in sum as may be required by the mayor and board of trustees. The bond shall be conditioned upon faithful
performance of the village collector of the duties of the office and shall be conditioned to indemnify the village for any loss by reason of any neglect of duty
or wrongful act on the part of the village collector.
(Ord. 71-0-184, passed 4-12-1971)
Village Treasurer
§ 31.120 CREATION OF OFFICE; APPOINTMENT.
There is hereby created the office of village treasurer. The treasurer shall be appointed by the president by and with the advice and consent of the board of
trustees and shall hold office for a period of 1 year unless otherwise provided by ordinance.
(1968 Code § 5.06) (Ord. 93-7-848, passed 7-12-1993)
§ 31.121 BOND.
The treasurer shall give bond in the sum as may be required by the board of trustees, but not less than the amount as may be required by state law. The
bond shall be conditioned upon the faithful performance by the treasurer of his duties of office and shall be conditioned to indemnify the village for any loss
by reason of any neglect of duty or wrongful act on the part of the treasurer.
(1968 Code § 5.06)
§ 31.122 DUTIES.
(A) The treasurer shall perform such duties as may be prescribed for him by statute or ordinance. He shall receive all money paid into the village, either
directly from the person paying the money or from the hands of the other officer as may receive it, and he shall pay out money only on vouchers or
orders properly signed by the president and the village clerk. He shall be the collector for all money due under special assessment and he shall keep a
separate and complete record of all money so received.
(B) He shall deposit the village funds in such depositories as are selected from time to time by the president and board of trustees, and he shall keep the
deposit of village money separate and distinct from his own money, and shall not intermingle his own money with the village money, and he shall not
make private or personal use of any village money.
(C) The treasurer shall keep the records showing all money received by him, showing the source from which it is received and the purpose for which it is
paid; and he shall keep records at all times showing the financial status of the village.
(D) The treasurer shall keep such books and accounts as may be required by statute or by ordinance, and shall keep them in a manner required by the
board of trustees.
(E) The treasurer shall make monthly reports to the board showing the state of the finances of the village, and the amount received and spent during the
month, which reports shall be filed. And the treasurer shall make an annual report between May 1 and May 10 with total amount of all receipts and
expenditures during the preceding fiscal year.
(F) The treasurer shall keep a register of all warrants, bonds or orders filed with him or paid by him and all vouchers, as is required by statute.
(1968 Code § 5.06)
§ 31.123 INVESTMENT POLICY.
The investment policy of the village, adopted by ordinance 01-2-1229, on February 12, 2001, is hereby adopted by reference and made a part of this code
the same as if set forth in full herein.
(Ord. 95-12-955, passed 12-11-1995; Am. Ord. 01-2-1229, passed 2-12-2001)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 23/360
Village Engineer
§ 31.150 CREATION OF OFFICE; APPOINTMENT.
There is created the office of the village engineer, an executive office of the village. The person filling this office shall be an Illinois registered professional
engineer. He shall be appointed by the president by and with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. The village engineer shall be subject to the
direction of the village administrator on a day to day basis.
(1968 Code § 5.07)
§ 31.151 DUTIES.
(A) It shall be the duty of the village engineer to attend such regular and special meetings of the board of trustees at which his presence has been
requested by the board of trustees.
(B) The engineer shall act as a consultant to the board of trustees on all matters pertaining to public improvements such as sidewalks, street pavement,
curbs and gutters, storm drainage, sanitary sewerage, water supply, water treatment and other municipal engineering problems.
(C) The engineer shall make such studies, reports, plans and specifications as he may from time to time be requested to make by the board of trustees.
(D) The engineer shall assist the village attorney and the superintendent of public works through provision of technical advice and services when directed
to do so by the board of trustees.
(E) The engineer shall prepare such reports and estimates as may be required in the routine administration of funds derived from the state motor fuel tax
law. He shall prepare specific plans and specifications for such specific maintenance and construction projects as may be financed or partially financed
by funds so derived.
(1968 Code § 5.07)
Health Officer
§ 31.165 CREATION OF OFFICE; APPOINTMENT.
There is hereby created the office of the health officer, an executive office of the village. He shall be appointed by the president by and with the consent of
the board of trustees.
(1968 Code § 5.03)
§ 31.166 DUTIES.
(A) It shall be the duty of the health officer to enforce all ordinances containing provisions for the protection of public health; to make inspections of
foodstuffs and of the premises used for storing or selling of provisions as may be required by ordinance; and to perform such other duties and functions
as may be required by law or ordinance.
(B) The health officer shall enforce all the rules and orders of the board of health; shall make such inspections as may be ordered by the board of health
and shall attend the meetings of the board when requested to do so by the presiding officer.
(C) The health officer shall make such reports to the board of trustees as may be required. He also shall recommend rulings, orders or ordinances
respecting the public health whenever he is requested to do so, or whenever he deems it advisable or necessary.
(1968 Code § 5.03)
Chapter 32
DEPARTMENTS, BOARDS, AND COMMISSIONS
Board Of Local Improvements
§ 32.01 CREATION.
There is hereby established the board of local improvements for the village, which shall consist of the president and all members of the board of trustees.
(1968 Code § 6.02)
§ 32.02 DUTIES.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 24/360
The board of local improvements shall have the powers and perform the duties assigned to it by statute or ordinance.
(1968 Code § 6.02)
Economic Development Commission
§ 32.10 PURPOSE.
The purpose of the economic development commission shall be to develop a plan for the maintenance and revitalization of economic growth within the
village by assuring opportunities for development or redevelopment and attracting sound and stable functions as the village president and board of
trustees shall from time to time designate.
(Ord. 91-10-791, passed 10-14-1991)
§ 32.11 MEMBERS; APPOINTMENT AND TERM OF OFFICE.
(A) The economic development commission shall be composed of 7 members who shall be known as commissioners. The commissioners shall be
appointed by the village president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. 1 commissioner shall be named as chairperson and 1
commissioner shall be named as vice chairperson at the time of appointment. The chairperson shall appoint 1 of the commissioners as secretary of the
commission. If any commissioner for whatever reason fails to complete his or her term, the village president, with the advice and consent of the board
of trustees, shall appoint a replacement to fill his or her unexpired term.
(B) The term of office for all members of the commission shall be for 3 years and said term shall expire on April 30 following their 3 year term.
(Ord. 91-10-791, passed 10-14-1991)
§ 32.12 ORGANIZATION.
The members of the economic development commission shall elect any other officers that they may deem necessary, and shall hold such meetings and
establish such rules and regulations as said commission shall deem necessary and proper for carrying on its functions. For meeting purposes, any 4
commissioners shall constitute a quorum.
(Ord. 91-10-791, passed 10-14-1991)
§ 32.13 POWERS AND DUTIES.
(A) The economic development commission shall assist both existing and prospective industrial or commercial firms to expand, extend, locate or relocate
in the village so as to coordinate and maximize business growth within the community.
(B) The commission shall cooperate with all other agencies of the village, county and state governments as well as such private organizations as will help
further the goals of the commission.
(C) The commission shall render advice and recommendations to the village president and village board as it may deem appropriate or as may be
requested.
(D) No member of the commission shall enter into any contractual obligation, pay bills, or solicit or collect money without approval and consent of the
village president and board of trustees.
(Ord. 91-10-791, passed 10-14-1991)
§ 32.14 BUDGET.
The economic development commission shall prepare an operating budget for each fiscal year and shall submit their budget request to the village board
before April 1 for the fiscal year beginning thereafter.
(Ord. 91-10-791, passed 10-14-1991)
Plan Commission
§ 32.25 CREATION; APPOINTMENT; CONCURRENT MEMBERSHIP.
(A) There is hereby created a plan commission for the village. The plan commission shall consist of 7 members to be appointed by the village president
with the advice and consent of the board of trustees.
(B) As of May 9, 2011, the members of the plan commission shall also serve as members of the zoning board of appeals, and the chair of the zoning board
of appeals shall also serve as the chair of the plan commission. The resignation, removal, or replacement of any member from the zoning board of
appeals shall be deemed to be a resignation, removal, or replacement from the plan commission. (Ord. 94-6-875, passed 6-13-1994; Am. Ord. 11-5-
1844, passed 5-9-2011)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 25/360
§ 32.26 TERM OF OFFICE.
(A) The term of office for each appointed member shall be 4 years except for any lesser term as provided in division (B) of this section and shall end with
April 30 in the year in which the term of office expires or until their successor is appointed.
(B) For the term starting in May of 2003, 2 members shall be appointed for 4 year terms and 2 members shall be appointed for 1 year terms and for the
term starting in May of 2005, 2 members shall be appointed for 4 year terms and 1 member shall be appointed for a 1 year term.
(C) As of May 9, 2011, the term of each member of the plan commission serving concurrently on the zoning board of appeals shall be that term for which
the member is appointed to the zoning board of appeals pursuant to ' 32.40 of this chapter.
(1968 Code § 6.03) (Ord. 63-0-81, passed 9-9-1963; Am. Ord. 68-0-140, passed 10-14-1968; Am. Ord. 73-0-238, passed 7-9-1973; Am. Ord. 03-5-
1319, passed 5-12-2003; Am. Ord. 11-5-1844, passed 5-9-2011)
§ 32.27 PROCEDURE.
Immediately following their appointment, the members of the plan commission shall meet, organize, elect officers as they may deem necessary, and adopt
and later change or alter rules and regulations of the organization and procedures consistent with statutes and village ordinances. The commission shall
keep written records of its proceedings which shall be open at all times to public inspection. The commission also shall file an annual report with the board
of trustees setting forth its transactions and recommendations.
(1968 Code § 6.03)
§ 32.28 DUTIES AND POWERS.
The plan commission shall have the following duties and powers:
(A) To prepare and recommend to the board of trustees a comprehensive plan of public improvements looking to the present and future development and
growth of the village. The plan, after its adoption by the board of trustees, will be known as the "official plan of Lindenhurst". The plan shall include
reasonable requirements in reference to streets, alleys and public grounds within the corporate limits and in contiguous territory outside of and distant
not more than 11/2 miles from the limits, and not included in any municipality, the requirements to be effective whenever the limits shall be subdivided
after the adoption of the plan.
(B) To prepare and recommend to the board of trustees from time to time such changes in the plan as may be deemed necessary by the board of trustees
or the plan commission.
(C) To prepare and recommend to the board of trustees, from time to time, plans and recommendations for specific improvements in pursuance of the
official plan.
(D) To aid village officials charged with the direction of projects for improvements embraced within the official plan, to further the making of the
improvements and generally to promote the realization of the official plan.
(E) To arrange and conduct any form of publicity relative to its activities or the general purpose of public understanding.
(F) To exercise the other powers germane to the powers granted by this section as may be conferred by the board of trustees.
(1968 Code § 6.03)
§ 32.29 EXPENDITURES.
The commission may, at the discretion of the board of trustees, employ necessary help, whose salaries, wages and other necessary expenses shall be
provided from the public funds. If the plan commission shall deem it advisable to secure technical advice or service, it may be done upon authority from the
board of trustees and appropriations by the board of trustees therefor.
(1968 Code § 6.03)
§ 32.30 REMUNERATION.
All members of the plan commission other than the chairperson shall receive $30 for each plan commission meeting attended by them. The chairperson
shall receive $40 for each plan commission meeting attended.
(Ord. 94-6-875, passed 6-13-1994; Am. Ord. 08-8-1731, passed 8-25-2008)
Zoning Board Of Appeals
§ 32.40 CREATION; CONCURRENT MEMBERSHIP.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 26/360
(A) The zoning board of appeals is created by the zoning ordinance of the village. The manner of appointment, terms of office, procedures, duties and
powers of the zoning board of appeals shall be as provided in division (B) of this section and chapter 159 of this code.
(B) As of May 9, 2011, the members of the zoning board of appeals shall also serve as members of the plan commission, and the chair of the plan

concurrently on the plan commission shall coincide with the member's remaining plan commission term. Upon the expiration of the plan commission
