Board Of Fire And Police Commissioners
§ 32.65 CREATED; COMPOSITION.
There is hereby created a board of fire and police commissioners consisting of 3 members. They shall be officers of the municipality as provided by
statute.
(Ord. 80-9-459, passed 9-22-1980)
§ 32.66 APPOINTMENT; TERMS.
The board of fire and police commissioners shall be appointed by the mayor of the village, by and with the consent of the board of trustees. The terms of
office of the members of the board of fire and police commissioners shall be 3 years and until their respective successor shall be appointed and qualified;
provided, that no appointments shall be made by any mayor within 30 days before the expiration of his term of office; provided further that the mayor shall
appoint the first members of the board, 1 of whom is appointed to serve until the end of the current municipal year in which the appointment is made,
another shall serve until the end of the municipal year next ensuing, and the third shall serve until the end of the municipal year second next ensuing;
provided, that each of the first members of the board shall serve until his successor is appointed and qualified.
(Ord. 80-9-459, passed 9-22-1980)
§ 32.67 QUALIFICATIONS; OATH; BOND; REMOVAL.
The members of the board of fire and police commissioners shall have qualifications as are now or may hereafter be required of them by law. Each
member of the board of fire and police commissioners shall take oath or affirmation of office and shall execute and deliver to the village a bond in the sum
of $1,000 with such sureties as the mayor and board of trustees shall approve, conditioned for the faithful performance of the duties of his office. The
members of the board of fire and police commissioners shall be subject to removal from office in the same manner as other officers of the village.
(Ord. 80-9-459, passed 9-22-1980)
§ 32.68 POWERS AND DUTIES.
The board of fire and police commissioners shall have such powers and duties as are now, or as may hereafter be given to it by law, and shall appoint all
members of the police department of the village except the chief of police, which appointment shall be made by the village president by and with the
consent of the board of trustees.
(Ord. 80-9-459, passed 9-22-1980; Am. Ord. 83-4-508, passed 4-25-1983)
§ 32.69 COMPENSATION OF MEMBERS OF THE BOARD.
The members of the board of fire and police commissioners shall serve with such compensation as the corporate authorities may determine and provide
by ordinance.
(Ord. 80-9-459, passed 9-22-1980)

Lakes Commission
§ 32.85 PURPOSE.
The lakes commission shall consist of 9 members who shall advise the village board on issues regarding the management of lakes within the village.
(Ord. 94-9-894, passed 9-26-1994; Am. Ord. 01-1-1226, passed 1-22-2001)
§ 32.86 MEMBERS; APPOINTMENT AND TERM OF OFFICE.
(A) The lakes commission shall be comprised of 9 members who shall be known as commissioners. The commissioners shall be appointed by the village
president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. 1 commissioner shall be appointed chairperson at the time of appointment and his or
her designation as chairperson shall expire on April 30 in the year following the year of appointment. If any commissioner for any reason fails to
complete his or her term, the village president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, shall appoint a replacement to fill his or her
unexpired term.
(B) At all times there shall be 1 commissioner who shall represent each one of the following lakes: Waterford, Spring Ledge, Potomac and Linden. The
chairperson and 4 other commissioners shall represent all lakes within the village. At least 2 of the commissioners representing all lakes shall not live
on any lake in the village.
(C) All terms shall be 2 years in duration.
(Ord. 94-9-894, passed 9-26-1994; Am. Ord. 01-1-1226, passed 1-22-2001)
§ 32.87 ORGANIZATION.
The commissioners shall elect a recording secretary who shall be responsible for preparing meeting agendas, taking minutes of meetings and other duties
as prescribed by the commission. They shall hold such meetings and establish such rules as they shall deem necessary and proper for the carrying out of
their function. For meeting purposes, any 4 commissioners shall constitute a quorum.
(Ord. 94-9-894, passed 9-26-1994)
§ 32.88 DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES.
(A) It shall be the duty of the commissioners to advise the village board of trustees on lake management issues. It shall be the duty of the commissioners
in making recommendations to the village board to take into account the needs of all residents of the village. The final decision on all lake management
issues rests with the village board.
(B) The lakes commission shall have the following specific duties and responsibilities:
(1) Serve in a citizens advisory capacity to the mayor and village board of trustees;
(2) Serve as a sounding board for citizen input, inquiry and needs as they relate to lake management;
(3) Recommend maintenance work as it relates to shore erosion, water quality, storm drainage, access upgrades and improvements;
(4) Recommend the need to contract for management services regarding aquatic weed control, fisheries evaluation and other special and general lake
management needs;
(5) Review and recommend regarding public beach modifications as they relate to park district improvements and their impact to both neighboring
properties and overall general lake usage;
(6) Recommend certain needs based on consultation with appropriate qualified advisors regarding wildlife control measures; upstream and
downstream wetland and wildlife sanctuary maintenance techniques;
(7) Recommend budgetary needs for purchase of capital equipment, including consulting services specific to lake management and ongoing
maintenance;
(8) Recommend changes and additions to lake use regulations, ordinances and community service officer involvement;
(9) Recommend the need for public education programs, seminars, announcements and workshops and assist in their creation, planning and
undertaking in conjunction with the village and other outside agencies;
(10) Develop and deliver to the village board an annual plan no later than March 1 of each year outlining fundraising recommendations. The village
board would own direction and implementation of any aspects of the plan. The plan should include ideas to encourage citizens, organizations and
companies to donate funds for the maintenance of the Lindenhurst lakes. The commission shall participate in activities associated with the
implementation of the plan.
(Ord. 94-9-894, passed 9-26-1994; Am. Ord. 09-1-1754, passed 1-26-2009)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 28/360
Veterans' Memorial Commission
§ 32.90 PURPOSE.
The veterans' memorial commission shall be responsible for implementing Memorial Day and Veterans Day activities to honor our country's servicemen
and servicewomen and any other activities deemed appropriate by the village board.
(Ord. 06-3-1535, passed 3-13-2006; Am. Ord. 09-1-1752, passed 1-26-2009)
§ 32.91 MEMBERS; APPOINTMENT AND TERM OF OFFICE.
(A) The veterans' memorial commission shall be comprised of 7 members who shall be known as commissioners.
(B) The commissioners shall be appointed by the village president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. The term of the commissioners
shall be for a 2 year period beginning on May 1 and ending on April 30. The terms of the commissioner shall be for 2 year staggered terms. Every 2
years 1 of the commissioners shall be appointed as chairperson by the village president for a 2 year term ending on April 30. A member of Lindenhurst
VFW Post 4894 (Lindenhurst resident) will be appointed as 1 of the commissioners. A village board member will be appointed by the village president
to act as a liaison between the commission and the village board.
(Ord. 06-3-1535, passed 3-13-2006; Am. Ord. 06-10-1580, passed 10-23-2006; Am. Ord. 09-1-1752, passed 1-26-2009)
§ 32.92 ORGANIZATION.
The commission shall elect a recording secretary who shall be responsible for taking minutes of meetings, preparing agendas and other duties as
prescribed by the commission. The commission shall hold meetings and establish rules as are necessary to carry out their duties and responsibilities.
(Ord. 06-3-1535, passed 3-13-2006)
§ 32.93 DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES.
(A) It shall be the duty of the commissioners to advise the board of trustees on issues regarding the Lindenhurst Veterans' Memorial. The final decision on
all veterans' memorial issues rests with the village board.
(B) The veterans' memorial commission shall have the following specific duties and responsibilities:
(1) Serve in a citizens' advisory capacity to the village president and board of trustees.
(2) Serve as a liaison to the village residents and receive their input regarding issues involving the veterans' memorial.
(3) The veterans' memorial commission shall be responsible for planning and implementing Memorial Day and Veterans Day activities and public
education programs to honor our country's servicemen and servicewomen and any other ceremonial activities deemed appropriate by the village
president and board of trustees.
(4) Develop and deliver to the village board an annual plan no later than March 1 of each year outlining fundraising recommendations for the memorial.
The village board would own direction and implementation of any aspects of the plan. The plan should include ideas to encourage citizens,
organizations and companies to purchase pavers and plaques and to donate funds for the maintenance of the Lindenhurst Veterans' Memorial. The
commission shall participate in activities associated with the implementation of the plan.
(C) The commission shall hold meetings and establish rules as are necessary to carry out their duties and responsibilities.
(Ord. 06-3-1535, passed 3-13-2006; Am. Ord. 09-1-1752, passed 1-26-2009)
Environmental Commission
§ 32.100 PURPOSE.
The Lindenhurst environmental commission shall, as directed by the village board, plan and undertake various projects related to the environment and
beautification of the environment of the village and provide educational opportunities for village residents to learn more about the environment and natural
beauty of our area and work with the village board in furtherance of the policies and procedures approved by the board.
(Ord. 2015-1-1976, passed 1-26-2015)
§ 32.101 MEMBERS; APPOINTMENT AND TERM OF OFFICE.
(A) The environmental commission shall be comprised of up to 9 members.
(B) The commissioners shall be appointed by the village president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. The terms of the commissioners
shall be for a 3 year period beginning on May 1 and ending on April 30 and shall be alternating staggered terms. Every 2 years, 1 of the commissioners
shall be appointed as chairman by the village president for a 2 year term ending on April 30.
(Ord. 2015-1-1976, passed 1-26-2015)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 29/360
§ 32.102 ORGANIZATION.
(A) The commission shall appoint a secretary who shall be responsible for taking minutes of meetings, preparing agendas and other duties as prescribed
by the commission. The commission shall schedule and conduct meetings and establish rules as are necessary to carry out their duties and
responsibilities. For meeting purposes, any 4 commissioners shall constitute a quorum.
(Ord. 2015-1-1976, passed 1-26-2015)
§ 32.103 DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES.
(A) It shall be the duty of the commissioners to plan and undertake various projects listed in division (B) of this section or as specifically assigned to them
by the village board related to the environment and beautification of the environment of the village and provide educational opportunities for village
residents to learn more about the environment and natural beauty of our area.
(B) The environmental commission shall have the following specific duties and responsibilities:
(1) Serve in a citizens' advisory capacity to the village president and board of trustees.
(2) Plan and run the village's annual Earth Day/Arbor Day Celebration and village cleanup.
(3) Plan programs to promote the planting of the village flower, the daffodil, throughout the village and facilitate the sale of daffodil bulbs to village
residents.
(4) Plan programs to promote the planting of the linden tree throughout the village and facilitate the sale of linden trees to village residents.
(5) Seek community volunteers to assist this commission in performing its duties and responsibilities.
(6) Develop and deliver to the village board an annual plan no later than March 1 of each year outlining fundraising recommendations. The village
board would own direction and implementation of any aspects of the plan. The plan should include ideas to encourage citizens, organizations and
companies to donate funds to the environmental commission. The commission shall participate in activities associated with the implementation of the
plan.
(Ord. 2015-1-1976, passed 1-26-2015)
Chapter 33
POLICE DEPARTMENT
§ 33.01 COMPOSITION.
The Lindenhurst police department shall consist of the chief of police, 3 commanders and 11 police officers and such other part time police officers and
employees as may be lawfully provided by the village board from time to time. Should any commander position become vacant, an additional patrol officer
shall be temporarily authorized until the vacant commander position is filled.
(Ord. 00-6-1189, passed 6-12-2000; Am. Ord. 04-11-1430, passed 11-22-2004)
§ 33.02 APPOINTMENTS; EMPLOYMENT.
(A) Full Time Officers: All sworn full time members of the police department other than the chief of police shall be appointed by the board of fire and police
commissioners of the village1. The chief of police shall be appointed by the village president by and with the consent of the board of trustees.
(B) Part Time Officers:
(1) Hiring; Discharge; Terms Of Employment. All part time police officers shall be hired by the village administrator and shall be considered at will
employees, subject to discipline and discharge by the village administrator. The terms and conditions of their employment shall be set forth in the
village's employee handbook. The number of hours a part time officer may work within a calendar year is restricted to not more than 1,000 hours per
year.
(2) Employee Handbook. The village's employee handbook shall apply to all part time officers except those portions pertaining to full time employees of
the village.
(3) Hiring Standards.
(a) All part time police officers shall be qualified to enter and successfully complete any training mandated by the Illinois law enforcement training
standards board.
(b) The aforesaid hiring standard shall be submitted to the Illinois law enforcement training standards board, as required by statute.
(c) All part time officers employed by the village shall be subject to the following:
1. Criminal history check;
2. Background and personal history investigation indicating proper qualifications, character and behavior;
3. Possession of a high school diploma or equivalent;
4. Proof of required handgun training;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 30/360
5. Drug screening analysis;
6. Oral interview;
7. Psychological exam;
8. Medical exam.
(d) All part time officers employed by the village must meet all of the following standards:
1. Be at least 21 years of age.
2. Possess a high school diploma or GED certificate.
3. Possess a valid driver's license.
4. Possess no prior felony convictions.
(C) Commanders:
(1) Commanders shall be appointed by the board of fire and police commissioners of the village subject to the applicable state laws, rules of the
commission and the qualifications included in the position job description.
(Ord. 00-6-1189, passed 6-12-2000; Am. Ord. 05-5-1470, passed 5-9-2005; Am. Ord. 11-6-1848, passed 6-13-2011; Am. Ord. 12-6-1901, passed 6-
25-2012; Am. Ord. 12-9-1905, passed 9-10-2012)
§ 33.03 RANK.
The chief of police shall be the head of the police department and shall have supervision over all officers and members thereof. Following him in rank shall
be the commanders and other police officers.
(Ord. - - , passed 2-13-1984; Am. Ord. 95-8-937, passed 6-28-1995)
§ 33.04 DUTIES.
(A) Duties Of Chief:
(1) The chief of police shall be subject to the direction of the village administrator on a day to day basis. He shall be the chief executive officer of the
police department. He shall devote his whole time to the duties of this office, see that all laws and ordinances of the village are enforced and
promptly execute all orders and observe all rules and regulations set forth and adopted by the village board of trustees. He shall assign members of
the department for duties, detail members to special duties and shall have charge and custody of all property pertaining thereto. He shall have
supervision over all members of the department, be responsible for the proper management and conduct of the department and shall be the keeper
for the village jail and custodian of all persons confined therein.
(2) The chief of police shall have charge and custody of all communication systems used or required for the operation of the police department. He
shall keep or cause to be kept a record of all arrests made in conformity with the best possible police record systems.
(3) The chief of police shall keep records of all traffic violations or accidents and other accidents resulting in a loss of or damage or injury to persons or
property and shall supervise traffic control devices. He shall have the custody of and be responsible for all lost, abandoned or stolen property
recovered in the village and dispose of the same as provided by law.
(4) The chief of police shall be charged with the enforcement of all laws or ordinances of the village relating to the public peace, health and safety and
shall cooperate with other officials of the village in the enforcement of all provisions of this code. He shall cause nuisances to be removed, preserve
peace and order at elections and provide an adequate police force at every public assembly of citizens.
(5) The chief of police is empowered to make reasonable rules and regulations relating to routine work of the department which are consistent with this
code and not in conflict with the rules and regulations of the village board of trustees.
(6) The chief of police shall make an annual report to the village board of trustees showing the work carried on by the department during the preceding
year in such detail as may be required by the village board of trustees with suggestions and recommendations for the improvement of police service.
(7) The chief of police shall perform such duties included in the position job description and as may be assigned to them by the village administrator or
village board of trustees.
(B) Duties Of Commanders: Police commanders shall perform such duties included in the position job description and as may be assigned to them by the
chief of police.
(Ord. 95-8-937, passed 6-28-1995; Am. Ord. 05-5-1470, passed 5-9-2005; Am. Ord. 12-6-1901, passed 6-25-2012)
§ 33.05 CONDUCT OF MEMBERS; SUSPENSION.
(A) It shall be the duty of every member of the police department to conduct themselves in a proper and law abiding manner and to avoid the use of
unnecessary force. Officers shall not behave in any manner which is a discredit to the police department or in any way be guilty of conduct unbecoming
a police officer. Officers shall promptly obey all lawful orders from their superiors and maintain their uniform, equipment and person in a neat and
orderly condition. Officers shall pay their debts promptly and not be seen in the company of or associated with persons of doubtful or questionable
character. Officers shall obey and abide by the laws and regulations set forth by the chief of police and the village board of trustees. In the performance
of their duty, officers must maintain decorum and attention, command of temper, patience and discretion. Officers must at all times refrain from harsh,
violent, coarse, profane or insolent language and at the same time, when required, act with firmness and sufficient energy to perform their duty.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 31/360
Drinking intoxicating liquor while on duty by any member of the police department is expressly forbidden, except when the consumption is in the line of
duty while participating in a police related investigation.
(B) The chief of police shall have the power to suspend any member of the police department from duty for a period not to exceed 5 days for violations of
this chapter, the rules and regulations of the police department, orders or other directives.
(C) In lieu of suspending any member of the police department, the chief of police may submit written charges against a member of the police department
to the board of fire and police commissioners of the village. Rules governing the suspension or the placing of written charges before the board of fire
and police commissioners are governed by the Illinois Compiled Statutes.
(Ord. - - , passed 2-13-1984; Am. Ord. 95-8-937, passed 6-28-1995)
§ 33.06 WITNESS FEES.
Every member of the police department shall appear as a witness whenever this is necessary in a prosecution for a violation of a village ordinance or any
state or federal law, but no member shall receive any witness fee for service in any action or suit to which the village is a party. All fees, if any are due for
the service, shall be turned over to the village treasurer.
(Ord. - - , passed 2-13-1984)
§ 33.07 RETIREMENT AGE.
The age for retirement of all policemen or policewomen of the police department of the village is hereby established to be 60 years of age.
(Ord. - - , passed 2-13-1984)
§ 33.08 MANUAL OF POLICE RULES AND REGULATIONS.
(A) The manual of police rules and regulations heretofore passed by the village board of trustees on March 10, 1986, and amended from time to time shall
remain in full force and effect subject to further amendment by the village board of trustees or as provided for in division (B) of this section.
(B) The chief of police may request amendments to the manual of police rules and regulations by submitting the proposed amendment in writing to the
village administrator for his review. The village administrator in his discretion may, in writing, approve the proposed amendment, modify the proposed
amendment, or refer the amendment to the village board of trustees for its consideration and review. All amendments approved by the village
administrator following this procedure are hereby adopted and incorporated in the manual of police rules and regulations as if fully set forth herein.
(Ord. 86-3-595, passed 3-10-1986; Am. Ord. 93-8-852, passed 8-23-1993; Am. Ord. 95-7-933, passed 7-10-1995; Am. Ord. 96-9-988, passed 9-9-
1996)
§ 33.09 BENEVOLENT FUND.
(A) There is hereby created a fund to be known as the benevolent fund for the police department of the village.
(B) This fund shall be used for the following purposes:
(1) Rendering aid to a police officer or the officer's immediate family in case of death, sickness or injury of such officer by acts in the line of duty.
(2) Improvement of the public image of the police department.
(3) Contributions by the police department to charitable or community sponsored projects.
(4) Special projects that benefit the police department.
(C) The police department is hereby authorized to conduct dances and other fundraising projects, the proceeds of which shall be deposited in this fund.
(D) It shall be the duty of the police department to recommend to the village board the expenditures to be made out of this fund. For anyone to be eligible
to receive benefits from this fund, the majority of the police department must vote in favor of the disbursement.
(E) The village treasurer is appointed treasurer of the fund and the depositories and the making of disbursements of this fund shall be ordered in every
respect as a general village fund, under the same procedures as a general village fund, except, however, that any disbursements shall not be made
without the prior consent of the majority of the police department.
(1968 Code, § 7.03; Am. Ord. 63-0-82, passed 12-9-1963; Am. Ord. 84-4-533, passed 4-9-1984)
§ 33.10 CHARGES FOR POLICE REPORTS.

and other applicable village ordinances shall pay the following processing charges:
Traffic accident reports $5

https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 32/360
All other reports (per page) $1
(Ord. 91-9-790, passed 9-23-1991)
§ 33.11 POLICE PENSION BOARD.
(A) Board Created: There is hereby created a board of trustees of the police pension fund of the village. The board shall be composed of 5 members, a
majority of whom shall be residents of the village. The board shall administer the pension fund and designate the beneficiaries thereof.
(B) Appointment Of Members To The Board: 2 members of the board shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the board of trustees.
The third and fourth members of the board shall be elected from the regular police force by the active members thereof. The fifth member shall be
elected by and from among the beneficiaries of the fund.
(C) Term Of Office: 1 of the board members appointed by the mayor shall serve for 1 year beginning on the second Tuesday in May after the village comes
within the provisions of the police pension fund. The other member appointed by the mayor shall serve for 2 years beginning on the same date. The
successors to any of the appointed members of the board by the mayor shall serve for 2 years each or until their successors are appointed and
qualified. The election of the third and fourth members of the board from the regular police force by the active members thereof shall be held biennially
on the third Monday in April, at such place or places in the municipality and under the Australian ballot system and such other regulations as shall be
prescribed by the appointed members of the board. All members of the regular police force shall be entitled to vote for the police force members of the
board. The fifth member of the board shall be elected by and from among the beneficiaries of the fund who are of legal age. All such beneficiaries of
legal age shall be entitled to vote for the member chosen from among the beneficiaries. No person shall be entitled to cast more than 1 ballot at such
election. The third, fourth and fifth members of the board shall be elected for a term of 2 years beginning on the second Tuesday of the first May after
such election. Upon the death, resignation or inability to act of any elected member of the board, his successor shall be elected for the unexpired term
at a special election, to be called by the board and conducted in the same manner as the regular biennial election.
(D) Powers And Duties Of The Board: The board shall have the power and duties as set forth and stated in 40 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-132 through
5/3-140 inclusive; and, in addition, all other powers and duties as granted to said board by the provisions of 40 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-101
through 5/3-152.
(E) Board Members: The board shall hold regular quarterly meetings on the second Tuesday of July, October, January and April annually, and special
meetings, as called by the president. At the regular July meeting, the board shall select from its members a president, vice president, secretary and
assistant secretary to serve for the period of 1 year and until his respective successor is elected and qualified. The vice president shall perform the
duties of the president during any period of vacancy in that office, or during such time as the president is absent from the municipality, or for any other
reason is disqualified or by reason of illness or other causes is unable to perform his duties. The assistant secretary shall act for the secretary
whenever necessary to discharge the functions of the office.
(F) Fund: The creation of the police pension fund for the village is hereby ratified and confirmed.
(Ord. 80-9-458, passed 9-22-1980; Am. Ord. 81-10-480, passed 10-26-1981)

Chapter 35
FINANCE AND REVENUE
General Provisions
§ 35.01 FISCAL YEAR.
The fiscal year of the village shall begin on May 1 and end on April 30 of the following year.
(1968 Code § 7.04)
Purchases And Contracts
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 33/360
§ 35.10 PURCHASE ORDERS.
(A) Required: All purchases over $1,000 shall require a purchase order. Any person requesting the purchase of items in excess of $1,000 must obtain a
purchase order approved by the applicable department head and, if applicable, the village administrator, prior to purchase or making any commitment,
agreement, or order for any goods, services, or merchandise. Once applicable approvals are obtained and the purchase order has been executed, the
purchase order shall be submitted to the village administrator's office for recordkeeping purposes.
(B) Exemptions: No purchase order is required for purchases below $1,000, which are subject to approval by the applicable department head. In addition,
the village administrator may approve exemptions from the purchase order policy for certain normal, routine, monthly operating expenses.
(Ord. 09-9-1776, passed 9-14-2009)
§ 35.11 COMPETITIVE BIDDING AND COMPETITIVE PRICE COMPARISONS.
(A) General: Except as otherwise provided in division (B) of this section, competitive bidding or competitive price comparison (as defined below) is required
for all purchases and contracts over $2,500 in accordance with the procedures set forth in § 35.12 of this chapter. All purchases and contracts over
$2,500 must be submitted to the village administrator for approval prior to competitive bidding or competitive price comparison. Where applicable, the
village administrator shall determine which contracts are competitively bid.
"Competitive price comparison" shall mean receiving and documenting pricing information on specified goods or services from at least 3 potential
suppliers, unless otherwise determined by the village administrator. Purchases shall be made from the responsible supplier who best meets the
village's needs. Reasons for selecting a supplier other than the supplier with the lowest cost shall be documented with the purchasing documents.
(B) Exemptions:
(1) The competitive bidding requirements and procedures set forth in the Illinois municipal code shall apply to all public works contracts that exceed
$20,000, unless otherwise authorized by a 2/3 vote of all trustees in accordance with state statute, 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8-9-1, as amended
from time to time.
(2) Except as specified elsewhere in this section, any labor, lease, goods, or service to be purchased, when the cost will exceed $20,000, shall be
purchased by a contract, or agreement, awarded to the lowest responsible bidder after advertising for bids, unless otherwise authorized by the board
of trustees.
(3) Contracts which by their nature are not adaptable to award by competitive bidding are exempt, such as:
(a) Contracts for the services of individuals possessing a high degree of professional skill where the ability or fitness of the individual is an important
factor, such as auditing, accounting, architectural, engineering, and legal services; and
(b) Contracts for services, training, and educational material where the ability or fitness of the trainer and/or quality of the materials plays an
important part; and
(c) Contracts for utility services, where no reasonable competitive alternatives are available, such as water, sewer, local telephone, natural gas and
electric services; and
(d) Contracts with the federal government or any agency thereof or purchases under the state of Illinois joint purchasing act.
(4) In the case of a bona fide emergency, a contract or agreement may be let or a purchase made, to the extent to resolve such emergency, without
competitive bids. Prior to making any purchase or contract hereunder, the village administrator shall obtain the verbal concurrence and within 24
hours or making any purchase or contract shall obtain written concurrence of the mayor and senior trustee, or in their absence, at least 2 other
trustees, that an emergency exists. The village administrator shall file a description of such expenditures, including amounts, in writing, with the
village board at its next regular meeting, and shall provide the date and time the emergency commenced and terminated, and the amount or
amounts expended.
(Ord. 09-9-1776, passed 9-14-2009)
§ 35.12 COMPETITIVE BID PROCEDURES.
(A) Advertisement For Bids:
(1) All proposals to award purchase orders or contracts requiring competitive bidding, as stated in § 35.11 of this chapter shall be published at least 10
days (excluding Sundays and legal holidays) in advance of the date announced for the receiving of bids, in a daily newspaper in circulation
throughout the municipality. Nothing contained in this section shall be construed to prohibit the municipality from placing additional announcements in
recognized trade journals.
(2) Advertisements for bids shall describe the character of the proposed contract or agreement in sufficient detail to enable bidders thereon to know
what their obligations will be, either in the advertisement itself or by reference to detailed plans and specifications on file at the time of the publication
of the first announcement. The advertisements shall state the date, time and place assigned for opening of bids.
(3) No bids shall be received at any time subsequent to the time indicated in the announcement; provided, that an extension of time may be granted for
the opening of the bids. The time of the bid extension opening shall not be less than 5 days after the publication thereof, Sundays and legal holidays
excluded.
(B) Opening Of Bids: All sealed bids shall be publicly opened and read by the village administrator or the village administrator's designee.
(C) Deposit On Bids: A cashier's check, a certified check, or a bid bond may be required of each bidder, but not to exceed 10% of the contract or purchase
amount if specified in the bid specifications.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 34/360
(D) Awarding Of Contracts: The award of any purchase order, contract, or agreement shall be in accordance with all applicable village ordinances.
(E) Determining Responsibility Of Bidders: In determining the responsibility of any bidder, the village board may take into account other factors in addition
to financial responsibility, such as past records of transactions with the bidder, experience, adequacy of equipment, ability to complete performance
within the specified time limit, and other pertinent considerations.
(Ord. 09-9-1776, passed 9-14-2009)
§ 35.13 INVALID CONTRACTS.
Any purchase or contract executed in violation of this chapter shall be null and void as to the village and, unless the village later ratifies such purchase, if
public funds have been extended thereon, the amount thereof may be recovered in the name of the village.
(Ord. 09-9-1776, passed 9-14-2009)
§ 35.14 CONTRACTS, WORK ORDERS, CHANGE ORDERS AND OTHER AGREEMENTS.
The village administrator is authorized to execute contracts, work orders, change orders, and other agreements (hereinafter referred to as "contracts") that
are specifically authorized by the village board, as well as contracts for routine day to day operating activities without specific contract approval by the
village board in accordance with the limits established below and in accordance with the purchasing policies of the village:
(A) Contracts that are specifically authorized by the village board.
(B) Contracts for routine operating activities specifically included in the approved fiscal year budget up to the limits provided for each activity in the budget
or other routine operation and maintenance activities not specifically included in the budget up to $5,000, provided funds are on hand to pay for the
resulting costs.
(C) Contracts for the services of individuals possessing a high degree of professional skill (as defined in § 35.11 of this chapter) which are included in the
approved fiscal year budget up to the limits provided for each professional service in the budget or for other professional services not specifically
included in the budget up to $5,000.
(D) Contracts for design and construction engineering, when the village board has formally authorized bidding of a project or included a project in the
approved fiscal year budget, up to the amounts for engineering in the project cost estimate which was the basis for bidding or approval of the project.
(E) Contract change orders in an amount up to $10,000 where it is determined that extra work is required outside of the original contract where: 1) the
work to be performed as an extra and is essential to the fulfillment of the contract, 2) the work could not reasonably be expected to be performed at a
lesser sum if the work was authorized through an independent contract rather than as an extra, and 3) the emergency nature of the work, the
availability of the contractor or materials or some other similar reason would not permit the extra work to remain uncompleted until the next regularly
scheduled village board meeting. In order to sign contract change orders in excess of $10,000, the village administrator must seek verbal approval of
the mayor and senior trustee, or in their absence at least 2 other trustees. All contract change orders will be subject to ratification by the village board
to confirm that they were signed in accordance with this subchapter. Within 24 hours, written concurrence shall be obtained.
(F) Engineering contract change orders in an amount of up to $5,000 of the original contract when unforeseen difficulties outside the control of the village
engineer result in an increase in the engineering contract amount that was included in the construction estimate. In order to sign engineering contract
change orders in excess of $5,000 of the original contract, the village administrator must seek verbal approval of the mayor and senior trustee, or in
their absence at least 2 other trustees. Within 24 hours, written concurrence shall be obtained.
(Ord. 09-9-1776, passed 9-14-2009)
