Chapter 115
FOOD
Bakeries
§ 115.01 DEFINITION.
For the purpose of this subchapter the following definition shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning:
BAKERY. Any place used for any process of mixing, compounding or baking, for sale or for the purpose of a restaurant, bakery or hotel, any bread,
biscuits, pretzels, crackers, buns, rolls, macaroni, cake, pies or any food product of which flour or meal is a principal ingredient, or in which any potato or
other chips are made or prepared. Licensed restaurants in which any of the foregoing food products are mixed and baked for consumption in the
restaurant only, and in places where food is baked for home use or consumption only, shall not be considered bakeries.
('68 Code, § 34.01)
§ 115.02 LICENSE PROVISIONS.
A license fee of $50 per year shall be paid for each bakery.
('68 Code, § 34.01) (Am. Ord. 73-0-225, passed 4-18-73; Am. Ord. 80-4-421, passed 4-14-80)
§ 115.03 SANITARY REQUIREMENTS.
Every place used as a bakery shall conform to the following requirements:
(A) The floors of all rooms shall be of the construction as to be well drained, in good repair, easily cleaned and shall be kept clean. Floors of kitchens and
other rooms where food is washed or utensils cleaned shall be impervious to water. The floor of every place used as a bakery, if below street level,
shall be constructed of cement, asphalt, tile laid in cement or other impervious material.
(B) All walls and ceilings in all rooms shall be kept in good repair, well finished in a light-colored material and clean. The walls of kitchens and other rooms
shall be smooth, finished in a light color and washable. Walls subject to splash or spray from sinks or other source shall be of impervious material.
(C) All rooms shall be provided with adequate and evenly distributed lighting. Kitchens and other rooms shall be provided with lighting equivalent to that
produced by one 100-watt bulb for each 100 square feet of floor area.
(D) All rooms shall be ventilated in a manner as to maintain them reasonably free from disagreeable odors. When natural ventilation is inadequate or
creates a nuisance to neighboring property, a system of forced draft ventilation may be required with the outlet at roof level or other point so as to
create no nuisance to other properties.
(E) Proper screening shall be maintained at all doors, windows and other openings to prevent access of flies, rats and other vermin. Screen doors shall be
self-closing and open outward. Windows shall be kept clean.
(F) Every bakery shall be provided with an adequate toilet room with approved flush toilets conveniently located for the use of the employees. There shall
be located in or adjacent to the toilet room an adequate and convenient wash bowl with hot and cold water and there shall be provided soap and
individual clean towels. The use of the common towel is prohibited. All fixtures and plumbing shall be properly constructed and shall operate efficiently.
Adequate ventilation shall be provided for all toilet rooms by an opening to the exterior of the building, but if the opening is inadequate, forced
ventilation may be required. All toilet, wash and dressing rooms shall be provided with self-closing doors, shall be well lighted and shall be kept at all
times clean and sanitary.
(G) The water supply shall be that furnished by a public water system. All heaters and fixtures shall be in connection with the water system.
(H) All display cases, windows, counters, shelves, tables, refrigeration equipment and utensils used shall be well finished, constructed so as to be easily
cleaned and shall be kept in good repair. They shall be kept free from dust, dirt, vermin, spillage of food materials and other contaminating substances.
No cracked, chipped or broken dishes or utensils shall be used in the preparation or service of food materials. All cloths used in wiping tables, counters
or other equipment shall be clean. Adequate sinks and hot water shall be provided for cleaning all dishes and utensils used in serving and preparing
food and beverage materials.
(I) After bactericidal treatment all eating and cooking utensils shall be stored in a clean place free from flies, dust or other contamination and shall be
handled by employees so as to avoid contamination.
(J) Every employee shall furnish annually the information, permit physical examination and submit laboratory specimens as the Health Officer may require
for the purpose of determining freedom from infection. Persons suffering from a fever, sore throat, boils, abscesses or other infection shall not be
employed in a bakery or as a food handler.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 142/360
(K) All employees shall wear clean outer garments and shall keep their hands clean, shall wash after toilet at all times during employment in a food shop.
Employees shall handle food materials, dishes and utensils in a way as to avoid contamination.
(L) No articles, polish or other substance containing any cyanide or other poison shall be used for cleaning or polishing of eating or cooking utensils.
(M) Dogs shall not be allowed on the premises.
(N) Food shall not be exposed or displayed on any sidewalk, street or other place except in a properly equipped bakery.
(O) The premises shall be kept clean and free from accumulations of litter or rubbish, flies, roaches, rats, mice, or other vermin.
('68 Code, § 34.03)
§ 115.04 PHYSICAL EXAMINATION OF BAKERY EMPLOYEES.
Prior to the issuance of a license for any bakery, the applicant shall present to the Village Collector a list of his employees and a certificate of a duly
licensed physician and surgeon of the village dated within 30 days of the application, certifying that the employees of the bakery are free from venereal or
contagious diseases. Applicant must also make affidavit on a form required by the collector that the list of names of employees submitted with the
application contains a full and complete list of all employees of the bakery. In case of a new employee during the fiscal year, a certificate showing the
condition of health of the new employee shall be presented to the Village Collector within three days after the employee enters upon employment. At the
time of the renewal of the license medical certificates shall again be furnished.
('68 Code, § 34.04)
§ 115.05 INSPECTIONS.
The Health Officer and authorized inspectors under the Health Department shall have a right at all times to enter to make inspection and record of the
condition of any bakery as they may deem necessary. If the inspection discloses a lack of conformity with the provisions of this subchapter, the Health
Officer may require the changes, alterations or renovations as may be necessary to make the bakery conform with the provisions of this subchapter. The
Health Officer may issue additional rules and regulations as in his opinion may be deemed in the interests of public health, upon notice to persons holding
licenses under this subchapter.
('68 Code, § 34.05)
Food Vendors
§ 115.20 DEFINITIONS.
For the purpose of this subchapter the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
FOOD DEALER. Every person, firm or corporation engaged in conducting or operating any of the following businesses:
(1) Fruit store or establishment for the retail sale of fresh fruit and berries.
(2) Grocery store, or establishment for the sale or retail of butter, cheese, vegetable or other provisions.
(3) Ice cream parlor.
(4) Restaurant.
(5) Meat market or establishment for the retail sale of fresh meat, poultry and fish.
(6) Retail beverage store.
FOOD. Any food or beverage intended for human consumption.
('68 Code, §§ 40.01, 40.08)
§ 115.21 UNWHOLESOME FOOD.
(A) No person, firm or corporation shall sell, offer for sale or keep for the purpose of selling or offering for sale, any food of any kind which is spoiled or
tainted or is unwholesome and unfit for human consumption, for any reason.
(B) All tainted or unwholesome food intended for human consumption may be condemned by the Board of Health, and shall thereupon be seized and
destroyed by the Board of Health, the Health Officer or Police Chief of the village.
('68 Code, § 40.02) Penalty, see § 115.99
§ 115.22 ADULTERATIONS.
It shall be unlawful to sell, offer for sale, or keep for the purpose, any food or drink intended for human consumption which has been adulterated by any
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 143/360
material harmful in any way, or which does not comply with the state statutes governing the same.
('68 Code, § 40.03) Penalty, see § 115.99
§ 115.23 SANITARY REGULATIONS.
Premises used for the sale or storage of food intended for human consumption must be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. It shall be unlawful to permit
any accumulation of refuse, or waste of any kind thereon for more than 24 hours; and it shall be unlawful to permit any decaying animal or plant matter to
remain on any premises at all.
('68 Code, § 40.04) Penalty, see § 115.99
§ 115.24 INSPECTIONS.
The Health Officer shall inspect or cause to be inspected, every place, building or establishment, used for the storage, handling, sale or preparation of food
or drink intended for human consumption. It shall be the duty of every food dealer to give to the Health Officer the samples of each food or drink as may be
necessary for the purpose of making an analysis of the same to determine whether it is clean and wholesome.
('68 Code, § 40.05)
§ 115.25 FLIES AND VERMIN.
Premises used for the storage of food intended for human consumption shall be kept free from flies and vermin of all kinds.
('68 Code, § 40.06)
§ 115.26 EMPLOYEES.
All persons engaged in handling or coming in contact with food or drink intended for human consumption shall keep themselves clean and shall keep their
clothes clean. It shall be unlawful to permit any person afflicted with a contagious or venereal disease to handle any food intended for sale for human
consumption or for any such person to handle any food.
('68 Code, § 40.07) Penalty, see § 115.99
Food Vending Machines
§ 115.40 DEFINITION.
AUTOMATIC FOOD VENDING MACHINE. The term when used in this subchapter shall mean any mechanical container or device used for the sale of
any beverage or article of food, the operation of which is governed or controlled by the deposit of a coin or token.
(Ord. 80-4-446, passed 4-48-73)
§ 115.41 LICENSE REQUIRED.
No person shall install, keep, maintain or use an automatic food vending machine in the village, or permit the installation, keeping, maintenance or use
upon his premises of an automatic food vending machine without first having obtained a license therefor; provided, however, that when the owner or
operator of an automatic food vending machine has obtained a license, the owner of the premises on which the machine is to be located need not obtain a
further license for the machine; and provided, further, that nothing herein contained shall require a licensed food establishment licensee under this
subchapter to procure a license for operating an automatic food vending machine owned by the licensee and operated on the licensed premises.
(Ord. 80-4-446, passed 4-18-73)
§ 115.42 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.
An application for a license to install, keep, maintain or use an automatic food vending machine shall be made in conformity with the general requirements
of this code relating to applications for licenses. The application also shall state the types of automatic food vending machines intended to be operated, a
description of each type, and the number of employees to be involved in servicing the machines.
(Ord. 80-4-446, passed 4-18-73)
§ 115.43 INVESTIGATIONS.
The Health Officer shall make or cause to be made investigation as he deems necessary to determine whether the applicant's automatic food vending
machine and automatic food vending operations comply with all the provisions of this code relating to health, sanitation and food and with all other
applicable provisions of this code. No license shall be issued to any applicant whose automatic food vending machine and automatic food vending
machine operations do not comply with the applicable provisions of this code. The Health Officer shall indicate on the application for a license the results
of his investigation and his approval or disapproval of the application.
(Ord. 80-4-446, passed 4-18-73)
§ 115.44 LICENSE FEE.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 144/360
The annual fee for a license to install, keep, maintain or use an automatic food vending machine shall be $25.
(Ord. 80-4-446, passed 4-18-73)
§ 115.45 GENERAL REGULATIONS.
(A) Compliance Required. All persons licensed hereunder to install, keep, maintain or use an automatic food vending machine, whether licensed under this
subchapter or under another subchapter in this code, shall comply strictly with all the regulations of Chapter 110 and all applicable regulations of this
code, except that no lavatory or toilet facilities or clothing storage area need be provided where employees in food contact activities are not present for
more than one hour a day.
(B) Premises. No automatic food vending machine shall be located in any premises that expose the food to danger from improper handling, dust, dirt, flies,
vermin or other contamination. No automatic food vending machine shall be installed or kept in any toilet or washroom.
(C) Operator's Place of Business.
(1) The Village President shall be notified of any change in the address of the operator's place of business and the current address, along with the
operator's name, shall be indicated in some conspicuous place on each of the machines.
(2) There shall be posted in a conspicuous place on each machine the name, address and telephone number of the person responsible for the
maintenance of the machine.
(Ord. 80-4-446, passed 4-18-73) Penalty, see § 115.99
§ 115.46 INSPECTIONS.
The Health Officer shall inspect or cause to be inspected as often as he deems necessary every automatic food vending machine and automatic food
vending machine operation located and conducted in the village to determine whether all applicable provisions of this code are being complied with. The
investigation shall be made in accordance with Chapter 110 of this code.
(Ord. 80-4-446, passed 44 8-73)
Restaurants
§ 115.60 APPLICABILITY OF REGULATIONS.
The provisions of this subchapter apply to restaurants and itinerant restaurants.
('68 Code, § 49.03)
§ 115.61 DEFINITIONS.
For the purpose of this subchapter the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
ITINERANT RESTAURANT. A restaurant operating for a temporary period in connection with a fair, carnival, circus, public exhibition, or other similar
gathering.
RESTAURANT. Any restaurant, coffee shop, cafeteria, short order cafe, luncheonette, tavern, sandwich stand, soda fountain, and any other eating or
drinking establishment, or kitchen or other place in which food or drink is prepared for sale elsewhere.
('68 Code, § 49.01)
§ 115.62 LICENSE PROVISIONS.
The annual license fee is $50 for a restaurant and $100 for an itinerant restaurant.
('68 Code, § 49.02) (Am. Ord. 80-4-435, passed 4-14-80)
§ 115.63 INSPECTIONS.
It shall be the duty of the Health Officer, from time to time, to inspect and examine all restaurants for the purpose of ascertaining whether all subchapters of
the village and the laws of the state relative to the keeping of restaurants are being complied with. It shall be the duty of every keeper of a restaurant to
permit the inspections to be made, and when required to furnish samples of any food kept, sold, offered for sale or served in the restaurants, which
samples shall be examined or analyzed by, or under the direction of the Health Officer. A record of each examination or analysis shall be made and kept
on file in his office.
('68 Code, § 49.04)
§ 115.64 LIGHTING.
All rooms or places of a restaurant shall be properly and adequately lighted so that all parts may be inspected readily.
('68 Code, § 49.05)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 145/360
§ 115.65 WALLS AND CEILINGS.
The walls and ceilings, shall be smooth, hard material and must be kept clean and sanitary and in good repair. All walls and ceilings of rooms in which food
or drink is stored or prepared shall be finished in light color. The walls of all rooms in which food or drink is prepared or utensils are washed shall have a
smooth, washable surface up to the level reached by splash or spray.
('68 Code, § 49.06)
§ 115.66 RESTAURANT FLOORS.
The floors of all rooms in which food or drink is stored, prepared, or served, or in which utensils are washed, shall be of smooth, hard material and must be
kept clean and sanitary and in good repair at all times.
('68 Code, § 49.07)
§ 115.67 COUNTERS, SHELVES, SHOW CASES AND WINDOWS.
All show or display cases or windows, counters or shelves, used in keeping and displaying food and drink shall be kept clean and sanitary, free from dust,
dirt and other contaminating material, and in good repair. All food containers shall also be elevated at least two feet from the floor.
('68 Code, § 49.08)
§ 115.68 TOILET AND LAVATORY FACILITIES.
(A) Every restaurant shall be provided with adequate and conveniently located toilet facilities for its employees, conforming with the provisions of this code.
In restaurants hereafter constructed toilet rooms shall not open directly into any room in which food, drink, or utensils are handled or stored. The doors
of all toilet rooms shall be self-closing. Toilet rooms shall be kept in a clean condition, in good repair, and well-lighted and ventilated. Handwashing
signs shall be posted in each toilet room used by employees.
(B) Adequate and convenient handwashing facilities shall be provided, including warm water, soap, and approved sanitary towels. The use of a common
towel is prohibited. No employee shall resume work after using the toilet room without washing his hands.
('68 Code, §§ 49.09, 49.15)
§ 115.69 SINKS.
Sinks with an adequate supply of hot and cold running water of safe, sanitary quality shall be provided with metallic splash boards approved by the Health
Officer. All sinks shall be constructed of non-absorbent material.
('68 Code, § 49.10)
§ 115.70 GREASE TRAPS.
Each restaurant shall be provided with a grease trap installed in strict compliance with the plumbing regulations of the village. Upon a written agreement
not to do cooking, requiring an extensive washing of greasy equipment, pans, dishes or other utensils, the Health Officer may, in his discretion waive the
requirement of this section relative to grease traps, the waiver to be conditional upon compliance with the aforesaid written agreement.
('68 Code, § 49.11)
§ 115.71 UNSANITARY ROOMS.
No restaurant shall be conducted in a room or rooms used for sleeping purposes or in any room or place that is dark, damp, poorly ventilated, or
unsanitary.
('68 Code, § 49.12)
§ 115.72 DOORS AND WINDOWS TO BE SCREENED.
All doors, windows, and other openings shall be properly screened from May 1 to October 31 of each year. Screen doors shall be provided with selfclosing
devices.
('68 Code, § 49.13)
§ 115.73 REFRIGERATORS.
All refrigerators, ice boxes and other appurtenances thereof used for the storage of food and drink shall be kept clean and sanitary and in good repair, and
the compartments used for the storage of ice shall be lined with some proper metallic substance so as to be water-tight. No food shall be placed directly on
ice or ice coils. All readily perishable food or drink shall be kept at or below 50 degrees Fahrenheit except when being prepared or served. Waste water
from refrigeration equipment shall be properly disposed of.
('68 Code, § 49.14)
§ 115.74 WHOLESOMENESS OF FOOD AND DRINK.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 146/360
All food and drink shall be wholesome and free from spoilage. All milk, fluid milk products, ice cream and other frozen desserts served shall be from
sources approved by the Health Officer. Milk and fluid milk products shall be served in the original containers in which they were received from the
distributor or from a bulk container equipped with an approved dispensing device. This requirement shall not apply to cream, which may be served from
the original bottle or from a dispenser approved for the service. All oysters, clams and mussels shall be from approved sources.
('68 Code, § 49.16)
§ 115.75 RESALE OF HANDLED FOOD.
No hotel, restaurant, lunch counter or other place where food is sold shall resell for food any food which has been sold to or handled by any customer.
('68 Code, § 49.17)
§ 115.76 ARRANGEMENTS OF STOVES.
All stoves, ranges, heaters, and hot water tanks shall be elevated and placed at least two feet from walls to assure easy access for cleaning and all stoves
shall be re-equipped with proper ventilation by auction or hood as approved by the Health Officer.
('68 Code, § 49.18)
§ 115.77 DISEASES.
(A) Notice shall be sent to the Health Officer immediately by the restaurant manager or by the employee concerned if he or any employee contracts any
infectious, contagious, or communicable disease, or has a fever, a skin eruption, a cough lasting more than three weeks, or any other suspicious
symptom. It shall be the duty of any employee to notify the restaurant manager immediately when any of the conditions obtain, and if neither the
manager nor the employee concerned notifies the Health Officer immediately when any of the condition obtain they shall be held jointly and severally to
have violated this section.
(B) When suspicion arises as to the possibility of transmission of infection from any restaurant employee the Health Officer is authorized to require any or
all of the following measures:
(1) The immediate exclusion of the employee from all restaurants;
(2) The immediate closing of the restaurant concerned until no further danger of disease outbreak exists, in the opinion of the Health Officer;
(3) Adequate medical examinations of the employee and his associates, with such laboratory examinations as may be indicated.
(C) A placard containing this section shall be posted in all toilet rooms.
('68 Code, § 49.19)
§ 115.78 HABITS OF EMPLOYEES.
(A) All persons handling food or drink shall be cleanly in their habits, must wash their hands before beginning work and after visiting toilet. Individual soap
and towels shall be provided for the employees.
(B) All persons handling food shall wear clean, washable outer garments and approved cloth head bands, hair nets, or caps. Adequate toilets, dressing
rooms, and lockers for each sex shall be provided for the employees.
('68 Code, §§ 49.20, 49.21)
§ 115.79 GARBAGE CANS.
Regulation water-tight, properly covered galvanized iron metal cans for receiving and holding without leakage all garbage and other waste material shall
be provided. A tight-fitting cover shall be provided for each can, and the cans shall be kept covered and elevated on a platform at least two feet high. All
garbage and other waste material shall be removed from the premises daily and shall not be allowed to become a nuisance.
('68 Code, § 49.22)
§ 115.80 SOILED LINEN CONTAINER.
A special covered container shall be provided for the storing of all soiled linen.
('68 Code, § 49.23)
§ 115.81 CLEANING, STORAGE, AND HANDLING OF UTENSILS AND EQUIPMENT.
(A) All equipment, including display cases or windows, counters, shelves, tables, refrigerator, stoves, hoods, and sinks, shall be kept clean and free from
dust, dirt, insects, and other contaminating material. All cloths used by waiters, chefs, and other employees shall be clean. Single-service containers
shall be used only once.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 147/360
(B) All multi-use eating and drinking utensils shall be thoroughly cleaned and effectively subjected to an approved bactericidal process after each usage.
All multi-use utensils used in the preparation or serving of food and drink shall be thoroughly cleaned and effectively subjected to an approved
bactericidal process immediately following the day's operation. Drying cloths, if used, shall be clean and shall be used for no other purpose.
(C) After bactericidal treatment no utensil shall be stored except in a clean dry place protected from flies, dust, or other contamination, and no utensil shall
be handled except in a manner as to prevent contamination as far as practicable. Single-service utensils shall be purchased only in sanitary containers,
shall be stored therein in a clean dry place until used, and shall be handled in a sanitary manner.
('68 Code, §§ 49.24, 49.27)
§ 115.82 STEAM TABLES.
All steam tables shall be maintained at a temperature of at least 155° F. while containing food and shall be cleaned daily.
('68 Code, § 49.25)
§ 115.83 UTENSILS PROHIBITED.
(A) The use of any utensils used in the preparation, service, and sale of food or drink which is badly worn or rusted, or the use of cracked dishes or
glassware in a condition that it cannot be rendered clean and sanitary by washing, is prohibited.
(B) Equipment or utensils made of crockery, pottery, porcelain, enamelware or other material, the surface of which may become chipped or otherwise
damaged to an extent that dirt, grease, verdigris or disease germs may collect or stick to the damaged edges, or whose damaged edges chip or
become loose and get into food, or endanger life or health shall not be used after the damage or break of the inside surface is present, but shall at
once be discarded or repaired.
('68 Code, § 49.26) Penalty, see § 115.99
§ 115.84 USE OF TOBACCO.
The use of tobacco in any form is prohibited in rooms in which food is prepared.
('68 Code, § 49.27)
§ 115.85 STORAGE AND DISPLAY OF FOOD AND DRINK.
All food and drink shall be so stored and displayed as to be protected from dust, flies, vermin, unnecessary handling, droplet infection, overhead leakage,
and other contamination. No animals or fowls shall be kept or allowed in any room in which food or drink is prepared or stored. All means necessary for the
elimination of flies shall be used.
('68 Code, § 49.29)
§ 115.86 COMMON SUGAR BOWLS.
It shall be unlawful for any restaurant to place for public use any open sugar bowl where sugar is available to all persons by the use of a spoon. This
Section does not prohibit dispensers where the sugar dispenser is enclosed by a top with a small hole and the sugar is obtained by shaking or tipping the
dispenser.
('68 Code, § 49.30)
§ 115.87 DISORDERLY CONDUCT.
No restaurant licensee shall permit any person under the influence of liquor to frequent the restaurant or permit any person to engage in disorderly conduct
or in any lewd or lascivious behavior in place of business.
('68 Code, § 49.31)
Penalty
§ 115.99 PENALTY.
See General Penalty in Title I of this Code.
('68 Code, §§ 34.06, 40.09, 49.32) (Am. Ord. 80-4-421, passed 4-14-80; Am. Ord. 80-4-435, passed 4-14-80; Am. Ord. 80-4-446, passed 4-14-80; Am.
Ord. 96-4-975, passed 4-22-96)
Chapter 116
OTHER BUSINESSES
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.

Banks And Currency Exchanges
§ 116.001 LICENSE REQUIRED.
No person shall conduct, operate or engage in a general banking business, a savings and loan business, a currency exchange business or a safe deposit
vault business without first having obtained a license therefor.
(Ord. 80-4-448, passed 4-14-1980)
§ 116.002 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.
An application for the license shall be made in conformity with the general requirements of this code relating to applications for licenses.
(Ord. 80-4-448, passed - - )
§ 116.003 LICENSE FEE.
The annual fee for engaging in a general banking business, savings and loan business, safe deposit vault business or currency exchange business shall
be $50; provided, however, that if more than one business is conducted on the same premises by the same person, only one license and the payment of
one fee shall be required.
(Ord. 80-4-448, passed - - )
Barbers And Barbershops
§ 116.015 DEFINITION.
BARBER SHOP. Any building, room, place or establishment wherein the occupation is carried on of shaving or trimming the beard or cutting and dressing
the hair of patrons for a consideration.
(Ord. 80-4-422, passed 4-14-80)
§ 116.016 LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE.
No person shall conduct or operate a barber shop in the village without first having obtained a license therefor. The annual fee for a barber shop license
shall be $50.
(Ord. 80-4-422, passed 4-14-80)
§ 116.017 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.
An application to conduct or operate a barber shop shall be made in conformity with the general requirements of this code relating to applications for
licenses. The application also shall state the number of chairs to be used in the barber shop.
(Ord. 80-4-422, passed 4-14-80)
§ 116.018 INVESTIGATION OF APPLICANT.
The Health Officer shall make or cause to be made the investigation as he deems necessary to determine whether the applicant's proposed place of
business and the methods and equipment intended to be used by the applicant comply with all the sanitation, health and other applicable provisions of this
code and state statutes. No license shall be issued to any applicant whose proposed place of business and methods and equipment do not comply with
the applicable provisions of this code and statutes. The Health Officer shall indicate on the application for a license the results of his investigation and his
approval or disapproval of the application.
(Ord. 80-4-422, passed 4-14-80)
§ 116.019 SANITARY REQUIREMENTS.
It shall be the duty of every person licensed to conduct a barber shop to keep the licensed premises in a clean and proper sanitary condition at all times.
All necessary measures shall be taken to safeguard properly the life and health of patrons and all persons engaged therein against communicable and
contagious diseases. No person shall be permitted to be employed or engaged in the shaving, hair cutting or related work on patrons who shall be afflicted
with any communicable or contagious disease. All persons employed or working in the licensed premises as barbers shall keep themselves and their
clothing clean, and shall be required to wash their hands immediately before serving a customer. All towels and washcloths shall be washed with soap and
water and boiled before being used. It shall be unlawful to use any towel or washcloth on more than one customer without first having sterilized and
cleaned the implement or tool. There shall be provided separate receptacles for soiled towels and separate receptacles for discarded shaving and other
paper.
(Ord. 80-4-422, passed 4-14-80)
§ 116.020 INSPECTIONS.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 149/360
The Health Officer shall inspect or cause to be inspected as often as he deems necessary every barber shop in the village to determine whether all
applicable provisions of this code and state statutes are being complied with.
(Ord. 80-4-422, passed 4-14-80)
Billposting And Handbill Distribution
§ 116.030 DEFINITIONS.
For the purpose of this subchapter the following definition shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
BILL POSTER. Any person engaging in the business for hire of posting any written, painted or printed matter (hereinafter called a sign), to any outdoor
billboard, or to or upon any bridge, fence, pole, post, sidewalk, tree, or the exterior of any other structure except any sign mounted on, fastened to, or
suspended from the outside of any building or other structure in accordance with and authorized by any provisions of ordinance or statute regulating the
construction or use of so-called outdoor display signs, whether the display signs are illuminated or not.
COMMERCIAL HANDBILL. Any printed or written matter, any sample or device, dodger, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, paper, booklet or any other printed or
otherwise reproduced original or copies of any matter or literature which is used for commercial advertising.
HANDBILL DISTRIBUTOR. Any person engaged in the business for hire or gain of distributing commercial or non-commercial handbills other than
newspapers distributed to subscribers thereof and any person receiving compensation directly or indirectly for the distribution of the handbills.
NEWSPAPER. Any periodical or magazine regularly published with not less than four issues per year and sold to the public.
NON-COMMERCIAL HANDBILL. Any printed or written matter, any sample or device, dodger, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, newspaper, magazine, paper
booklet, or any other printed or otherwise reproduced original or copies of any matter or literature not included in the aforesaid definition of a sign, or a
commercial handbill, or a newspaper.
PRIVATE PREMISES. Any dwelling, house, building or other structure designed or used either wholly or in part for private residential purposes, and any
yard, grounds, walk, driveway, porch, steps vestibule or mailbox belonging or appurtenant to the dwelling, house, building or other structure.
PUBLIC PLACE. Any street, alley or other public way, public park, square, space, grounds or building.
('68 Code, § 42.01)
§ 116.031 DISTRIBUTOR'S LICENSE.
(A) The annual license fee for the license shall be $50.
(B) Persons acting for licensees as agents or employees in the posting or distributing of any signs or handbills are not required to obtain a license or pay a
fee, but each person shall comply with the provisions hereof.
('68 Code, § 42.02) (Am. Ord. 80-4-429, passed - - )
§ 116.032 EXEMPTIONS.
The provisions of this subchapter do not apply to the distribution of mail or to newspapers.
('68 Code, § 42.03)
§ 116.033 POSTING BILLS; AUTHORITY OF VILLAGE REQUIRED.
(A) No person shall post, stick, stamp, paint or otherwise fix, or cause the same to be done by any person, any notice, placard, bill, card, poster,
advertisement or other paper or device to or upon any sidewalk, crosswalk, curb or any portion or part of any public way or public place, or to any lamp
post, electric light, telegraph, telephone pole, railway structure, hydrant shade tree or tree-box, or to any part of any public bridge or viaduct or other
public structure of building, or upon any pole, box or fixture of the fire alarm or police telegraph system, except as may be authorized or required by law
or ordinance.
(B) No person shall, without the consent of the owner or occupant of the premises or of the President and Board of Trustees, on any public property, post,
stick or place any handbill, placard or notice upon any building, wall, fence, telegraph, telephone, or electric light pole or tree box, or shall mark,
scratch, cut or otherwise deface any part of any building, fence or tree box.
('68 Code, § 42.05) (Ord. 84-8-859, passed 8-27-84) Penalty, see § 116.999
§ 116.034 THROWING HANDBILLS IN PUBLIC PLACES.
No person shall distribute, cast, throw or place in or upon or along any of the streets, alleys or public places of the village any handbills, pamphlets,
circulars, books or advertising for the purpose or with the intent of advertising or making known any business, occupation, profession, medical treatment,
medicine or any other commercial matter.
(Ord. 84-8-869, passed 8-27-84) Penalty, see § 116.999
§ 116.035 PLACING HANDBILLS ON VEHICLES.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 150/360
No person shall deposit or throw any commercial or non-commercial handbill in or upon any vehicle. This subchapter does not prohibit the distributing of
any non-commercial handbill to the owner or other occupant of any automobile or other vehicle, who is willing to accept the same.
('68 Code, § 42.07)
§ 116.036 DISTRIBUTION OF HANDBILLS.
(A) No person shall deposit or throw any commercial or non-commercial handbill in or upon any private premises which are temporarily or continuously
uninhabited or vacant.
(B) No person shall deposit or throw any commercial or non-commercial handbill upon any premises if requested by anyone thereon not to do so, or if
there is placed on the premises in a conspicuous position near the entrance thereof a sign bearing the words: "No Trespassing," "No Peddlers or
Agents," "No Advertisement," or any similar notice indicating in any manner that the occupants of the premises do not desire to be molested or to have
their right of privacy disturbed or to have any handbills left upon the premises.
(C) No person shall deposit or throw any commercial or non-commercial handbill in or upon any private premises which are inhabited, except by handing
or transmitting the handbill directly to the owner, occupant, or other person then present in or upon the private premises. In case of inhabited private
premises which are not posted as provided in this chapter the person, unless requested by anyone upon the premises not to do so, may place or
deposit any handbill in or upon the inhabited private premises if the handbill is so placed or deposited as to prevent the handbill from being blown or
drifted about the premises or elsewhere.
('68 Code, § 42.08) Penalty, see § 116.999
§ 116.037 NAME OF PRINTER AND DISTRIBUTOR.
No person shall deposit or circulate any commercial or non-commercial handbill in any place which does not have printed on the cover, front or back
thereof the name and address of the following:
(A) The person who printed, wrote, compiled or manufactured the same.
(B) The person who caused the same to be distributed. In the case of a fictitious person or club, in addition to the fictitious name, the true names and
addresses of the owners, managers or agents of the person sponsoring the handbill shall also appear thereon.
('68 Code, § 42.09)
Christmas Tree Sales
§ 116.050 LICENSE REQUIRED.
No person shall sell or offer to sell any Christmas tree, or other tree offered or used as a Christmas tree, without first obtaining a license therefor as
provided in Chapter 110.
('68 Code, § 37.01)
§ 116.051 BOND.
Applicant for the license shall file a cash bond in the amount of $100 for each sales location, guaranteeing, the clean-up of the premises upon the
termination of Christmas tree sales thereon. The bond shall be refunded five days after the termination of sales upon the premises if the premises are
restored to a clean and sanitary condition as certified by the Health Officer.
('68 Code, § 37.02)
§ 116.052 LICENSE FEE.
The annual fee for a license to sell Christmas trees is $50.
('68 Code, § 37.03) (Am. Ord. 80-4-424, passed 4-14-80)
§ 116.053 ENTRY ONTO PREMISES FOR INSPECTION.
The Health Officer may enter upon any premises, wherein the sale of Christmas trees is conducted for the purpose of making the inspections as are
reasonably necessary to enforce the ordinances of the village.
('68 Code, § 37.04)
§ 116.054 TERM OF LICENSE.
A license to sell Christmas trees shall be for a term of 60 days commencing November 1 and ending December 31.
('68 Code, § 37.05)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 151/360
§ 116.055 EXEMPTIONS.
Any person holding any retail license issued by the village shall be exempt from the provisions of §§ 116.051 and 116.052 of this subchapter.
('68 Code, § 37.06)
Drugstores And Druggists
§ 116.065 DEFINITION.
For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definition shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning:
RETAIL DRUGSTORE. Any building, room, place or establishment where prescriptions for drugs or medicines are filled or compounded, or where
medicines, drugs, chemicals therapeutic preparations, druggists sundries, invalid and infant foods, physicians' supplies, proprietary medicines, toilet
articles, and other articles commonly sold in drugstores are sold, offered for sale, or kept with the intention of selling at retail or for supply to physicians,
dentists, veterinarians or other practitioners.
('68 Code, § 38.01)
§ 116.066 LICENSE PROVISIONS.
The annual license fee for each retail drugstore is $50.
('68 Code, § 38.02) (Am. Ord. 80-4-425, passed 4-14-80)
§ 116.067 SANITATION.
No person shall maintain, operate or conduct any drugstore in an unsanitary condition. Unsanitary conditions shall be deemed to exist if drugs, medicines,
or food preparations in the process of production, preparation, storing, sale, or distribution are not securely protected from dust, dirt of flies or other foreign
or injurious contamination or if refuse, dirt or waste products are allowed to accumulate, or if measures, containers or other utensils or apparatus are not
kept clean, or if the clothing of operatives or persons employed in the handling or preparation of drugs, medicines or food preparations is unclean, or if
adequate toilet facilities, soap and clean towels are not provided for the employees.
('68 Code, § 38.03)
§ 116.068 ITINERANT VENDOR OF DRUGS.
No itinerant nor transient vendor of any drug, nostrum, ointment, or appliance of any kind intended for the treatment of disease or injury shall sell or give
away, or offer to sell or give away, any drug, nostrum, ointment or appliance shall by writing or printing, or any other method profess to cure or treat
disease or deformity by any drug, nostrum, ointment or appliance unless the vendor is licensed by the State Board of Health as an itinerant vendor of
drugs.
('68 Code, § 38.04) Penalty, see § 116.999
§ 116.069 POISONOUS MEDICINES.
No poisonous medicine decoction or substance shall be held for sale or sold, except for a lawful purpose and with proper motives and by persons
competent to give the proper directions and precautions as to the use of the same; nor shall any bottle, box, parcel or receptacles thereof be delivered to
any person unless the same is plainly marked on the outside "Poison," nor to any person whom the person delivering the same to has reason to think
intends it for any illegal or improper use or purpose.
('68 Code, § 38.05) Penalty, see § 116.999
§ 116.070 FRAUDULENT PRESCRIPTIONS.
No doctor, druggist or other person shall make, sell, put up, prepare, or administer any prescription, decoction, or other medicine under any deceptive or
fraudulent name, direction or pretense.
('68 Code, § 38.06) Penalty, see § 116.999
§ 116.071 DISTRIBUTING SAMPLES OF MEDICINES.
No person shall give away, deposit or otherwise distribute any sample package, parcel, box or other quantity of any nostrum, proprietary medicine, nor
other material of an alleged medicinal character or purporting to be a curative agency by means of depositing or leaving the same in any hallway, private
area, or yard, or on any doorstep or in any place in any street or public ground in the village. Nor shall any person distribute handbills, advertising
medicinal or curative remedies.
('68 Code, § 38.07) Penalty, see § 116.999
Filling Station Operators
§ 116.080 DEFINITION.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 152/360
For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definition shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning:
FILLING STATION. Any building, structure, premises, enclosure or other place within the village where a container or containers, tank or tanks, either
portable or stationary, and containing ether, carbon bisulfite, gasoline, naphtha, benzol, hydrocarbon (gas drips), liquefied petroleum gas, acetone,
kerosene, turpentine or other flammable liquids having a flash point below 165 degrees Fahrenheit, are kept or located for the purpose of selling, offering
for sale, or distributing any liquids from the container or tank.
(Ord. 73-0-230, passed 4-18-73)

No person, firm or corporation shall engage in the business of a filling station without first having obtained a license therefor.
(Ord. 73-0-230, passed 4-18-73)
§ 116.082 APPLICATION.
An application for the license shall be made in conformity with the general requirements of Chapter 110 of this code.
(Ord. 73-0-230, passed 4-18-73)
§ 116.083 INVESTIGATIONS.
Investigation shall be made as provided for in § 110.05 of this code.
(Ord. 73-0-230, passed 4-18-73)
§ 116.084 FEE.
The annual license fee for each filling station shall be in the amount of $20 per nozzle.
(Ord. 73-0-230, passed 4-18-73; Am. Ord. 73-0-235, passed 6-11-73; 80-4-442, passed 4-14-80)
§ 116.085 BUILDING AND FIRE REGULATIONS.
The construction, operation and maintenance of filling stations and filling station equipment, including tanks, and the requirements for safety clearances
around the same, shall be done in accordance with the applicable Building Code, Fire Prevention Code and other related ordinances of the village.
(Ord. 73-0-230, passed 4-18-73)
§ 116.086 INSPECTIONS.
Inspections shall be conducted and made as provided for in § 110.012, entitled "Licenses and Permits", of the village code.
(Ord. 73-0-230, passed 4-18-73
Fire Extinguisher Sales, Service
§ 116.100 CERTIFICATE OF FITNESS REQUIRED.
No person shall service, repair, fill or refill any portable fire extinguisher which is to be used, kept or maintained, or is displayed for use as a fire protection
device in or upon any vehicle, lot, building, structure or premises, or any portion thereof, unless the person shall have first made application for and
received from the health officer a certificate of fitness authorizing the person to perform the acts, of servicing, repairing, filling or refilling any portable fire
extinguisher.
('68 Code, § 39.01)
§ 116.101 APPLICATION FOR CERTIFICATE; FEE.
(A) The application for a certificate of fitness shall be in writing upon a form furnished by the Health Officer. The application shall be signed by the
applicant. An applicant shall be at least 21 years of age. The application shall contain:
(1) The full name of the applicant.
(2) The age, weight, height, color of eyes, color hair and sex of the applicant.
(3) The business and residence addresses of the applicant.
(4) The address to which applicant desires all notices required to be given under this section, to be directed.
(5) A statement of the applicant's experience and qualifications.
(6) If employed, the name and business address of the employer.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 153/360
(7) The other and further information reasonably related to the qualifications of the applicant as may be required by the Health Officer.
(B) A fee of $50 in cash or check payable to the Village Treasurer and two prints of a bust picture of the applicant one inch by one inch in size shall
accompany the application.
('68 Code, § 39.02) (Am. Ord. 80-4-426; passed - - )
§ 116.102 CHANGE OF ADDRESS.
Each person holding a certificate of fitness shall notify the Health Officer in writing of any change of his business, residential or notification address within
ten days after the change. Failure to give the notification shall constitute grounds for revocation of the certificate.
('68 Code, § 39.03)
§ 116.103 DENIAL SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF CERTIFICATE.
The Health Officer may deny an application for a certificate of fitness or may suspend or revoke any certificate of fitness if he finds that the applicant for or
holder of any certificate is unable to furnish satisfactory proof of qualifications or ability; is a negligent or careless person; has violated any provision of this
section; has violated any rule or regulation made by the Health Officer; or has been guilty of practices constituting fraud upon the public.
('68 Code, § 39.04) Penalty, see § 116.999
§ 116.104 FORM OF CERTIFICATE.
The certificate of fitness shall be issued by the Health Officer and shall be in the form of an identification card. The card shall:
(A) State the purpose for which it has been issued;
(B) State the date it is issued and the date of expiration;
(C) Contain information as may be necessary to identify the person to whom it is issued;
(D) Have affixed one print of the photograph of the person to whom it is issued;
(E) Have the signature of the person to whom it is issued;
(F) Have printed thereon in bold type the following: "This certificate identifies, but does not recommend, the bearer";
(G) Contain anything else that the Health Officer considers necessary and proper to effect the purposes of this section.
('68 Code, § 39.05)
§ 116.105 DISPLAY OF CERTIFICATE.
The certificate holder shall, upon request, show the certificate to anyone for whom he seeks to service, repair, fill or refill any portable fire extinguisher, or
to the Health Officer or his representative.
('68 Code, § 39.06)
§ 116.106 PROOF OF QUALIFICATION.
An applicant for a certificate of fitness shall furnish satisfactory proof to the Health Officer that he is familiar with the materials required to be used in
servicing, repairing, filling or refilling any portable fire extinguisher; that he is competent to do and perform all acts necessary or incidental thereto; and that
he is familiar with and knows the application of the requirements of the provisions of this subchapter and the laws, ordinances and regulations relating to
portable fire extinguishers. If the Health Officer determines that the applicant for any certificate conforms in all particulars with the requirements prescribed
by this subchapter, the Health Officer shall grant the certificate of fitness.
('68 Code, § 39.07)
§ 116.107 EXPIRATION OF CERTIFICATE.
Certificates of fitness are valid for one year from the date of issuance, unless a shorter time is provided for in the certificate.
('68 Code, § 39.08)
Florists
§ 116.120 DEFINITION.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 154/360
For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definition shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
FLORIST. Any person regularly engaged in the conduct of an established business for selling, at retail or wholesale, cut flowers, bridal bouquets, funeral
floral designs or growing plants from a fixed and permanent business location.
(Ord. 80-4-445, passed 4-14-80)
§ 116.121 LICENSE REQUIRED.
(A) No person shall engage in the business of retail florist or wholesale florist in the village without first having obtained a license therefor. A person who is
engaged in more than one business shall procure a separate license shall be required for each location to engage in business.
(B) It is unlawful to engage in the business of an itinerant retail or wholesale florist in the village, and the activities to engage in business.
(Ord. 80-4-445, passed 4-14-80) Penalty, see § 116.999
§ 116.122 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.
An application for any license under this subchapter shall be made in conformity with the general requirements of this code relating to applications for
licenses. The application shall also indicate whether the applicant desires to engage in the business of retail florist or wholesale florist.
(Ord. 80-4-445, passed 4-14-80)
§ 116.123 INVESTIGATION OF APPLICANT.
The Village President shall cause to be made the investigation as he deems necessary to determine whether the applicant's proposed place of business
complies with the applicable provisions of this code. No license shall be issued to any applicant whose proposed place of business does not comply with
the applicable provisions of this code.
(Ord. 80-4-445, passed 4-14-80)
§ 116.124 LICENSE FEE.
The annual fee for a retail florist's license or a wholesale florist's license shall be $50.
(Ord. 80-4-445, passed 4-14-80)
§ 116.125 SANITARY REGULATIONS.
(A) Every location, place or establishment where the business of a florist is conducted, managed or carried on shall be kept in a clean and sanitary
condition and free from vermin. No decayed, decaying, unwholesome, contaminated or diseased flowers or plants shall be allowed to remain in or
about the establishment. Adequate and convenient washing and toilet facilities shall be provided.
(B) No licensee shall sell or offer for sale any flowers or plants the sale of which is restricted by Federal or State law.
(Ord. 80-4-445, passed 4-14-80) Penalty, see § 116.999
§ 116.126 OFF-PREMISES SALES PROHIBITED.
No license shall be issued except for a fixed location. The sale of flowers, plants or floral bouquets designs on the public ways or at places other than
those at which the licensee is licensed is hereby prohibited.
(Ord. 80-4-446, passed 4-14-80) Penalty, see § 116.999
§ 116.127 INSPECTIONS.
The Village President shall cause to be made the inspection as often as he deems necessary, of all florist establishments to determine whether the
provisions of this code relating to health, sanitation and safety applicable thereto are being complied with.
(Ord. 80-4-445, passed 4-14-80)
Gun Dealers And Gunsmiths
§ 116.140 GUN DEALER'S LICENSE.
The annual fee for a deadly weapon license is $50.
('68 Code, §§ 41.01-41.03, 41.08) (Am. Ord. 73-0-226, passed 4-18-73; 80-4-428, passed 4-14-80)
§ 116.141 REPORTS AND REGISTER OF SALES OR GIFTS.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 155/360
(A) Every person dealing in deadly weapons shall deliver to the Village Police Chief on the first day of each month a legible and correct report of every sale
or gift made under authority of his license during the preceding month, which report shall contain the date of the sale or gift, and name of the purchaser
or donee with his address and age, the number, kind, description and price of the weapon, the number of the purchaser's permit and the proposed
purpose given by the person for the purchase of the weapon.
(B) Every person dealing in deadly weapons at retail shall keep a register of all the weapons sold, loaned, rented, or given away by him. The register shall
contain the date of the sale, loaning, renting, or gift, the number of the permit, the number of the weapon, the name and age of the person to whom the
weapon is sold, loaned, rented or given, the price of the weapon, and the purpose for which it is purchased or obtained. The register shall be kept open
for the inspection of the police at all reasonable times during business hours.
('68 Code, §§ 41.04, 41.05)
§ 116.142 RESTRICTIONS ON SALE OR GIFT.
It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, barter or give away to any person within the village any deadly weapon mentioned in this section except to
licensed dealers and to persons who have secured a permit for the purchase of the articles from the Village Police Chief as herein required. This does not
apply to sales made of the articles which are to be delivered or furnished outside the village.
('68 Code, § 41.06) Penalty, see § 116.999
§ 116.143 FIREARM OWNER'S IDENTIFICATION CARD REQUIRED.
It shall be unlawful for any person to purchase any deadly weapon mentioned in this chapter without first securing a Firearm Owner's Identification Card
from the Department of Law Enforcement of the state.
('68 Code, § 41.07) (Am. Ord. 80-4-428, passed 4-14-80) Penalty, see § 116.999
§ 116.144 GUNSMITH'S LICENSE.
The annual fee for a gunsmith's license is $50, but a person licensed under Chapter 110 is not required to pay the additional fee for engaging in the
business of repairing firearms, but shall make the additional report required by this subchapter.
('68 Code, §§ 41.09-41.11) (Am. Ord. 80-4-428, passed 4-14-80)
§ 116.145 GUNSMITH'S REPORT.
Every person licensed as a gunsmith shall make out and submit to the Village Police Chief on the first day of each month a legible and correct report of
each firearm received for repair during the preceding month, which report shall contain the date, name, physical description, age, address and occupation
of the owner of the firearm, the type of weapon, its make, serial number and bore and length of the weapon.
('68 Code, § 41.12)
§ 116.146 AIR RIFLE AND TOY WEAPON SALES LICENSE.
No licensees shall sell or give away any weapon to any person who is under the age of 13. In addition, no licensee shall sell or give away any weapon to
any person who has not secured a permit from the Village Police Chief to purchase the weapon in the manner herein provided.
('68 Code, §§ 41.13-41.17) (Am. Ord. 73-0-226, passed 4-18-73; 80-4-428, passed 4-14-80)
§ 116.147 REPORT OF SALES.
Every person licensed under this subchapter shall make out and deliver to the Village Police Chief on the first day of each month a legible and correct
report of every sale or gift made under authority of the license to sell the kind of weapon or other articles named in this subchapter during the preceding
month, which report shall contain the date of the sale or gift, the name of the purchaser or donee, his address and age, the number, kind, description and
price of the weapon or other article, the number of the purchaser's permit and the purpose of the purchase of the weapon or other article.
('68 Code, § 41.18)
§ 116.148 PERMIT TO PURCHASE AIR RIFLE OR AIR GUN.
(A) It shall be unlawful for any person to purchase any air rifle or air gun, or any toy firearm or other toy in the nature of a firearm in which any explosive
substance can be used without first securing from the Village Police Chief a permit to do so. Before any permit is granted, an application in writing shall
be made therefor, setting forth the name, address, age, height, weight, complexion, nationality, and other elements of identification of the person
desiring the permit.
(B) It shall be the duty of the Village Police Chief to refuse the permit to any person convicted of any crime or to any minor.
('68 Code, §§ 41.19-41.20) Penalty, see § 116.999
Hardware And Paint Store Operators
§ 116.160 DEFINITIONS.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 156/360
For the purpose of this subchapter the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
RETAIL. Sales other than those for the purpose of resale or for use by manufacturers, contractors, trades, railroads, public service corporations and
institutions, or for the supplying of branch or general establishments from a central depot or store, and shall not include the sale at retail of second-hand or
used goods, wares or commodities.
RETAIL HARDWARE STORE. Any building, room, enclosure, premises, place, establishment or part of an establishment in the village operated,
maintained, or conducted for the sale or offering for sale at retail of any of the following articles: hardware, tinware, aluminumware, enamelware, cutlery,
tools, implements, apparatus, machinery; plumbing, engineer's, janitors', blacksmiths' contractors' or electrical supplies; gas, plumbing or electrical fixtures;
other articles or wares made largely of metals; kerosene, rifles, shotguns and loaded shot shells or cartridges where not more than 25,000 are kept on
hand at one time; provided, however, that dealers or establishments or parts of establishments of a similar nature specifically defined and licensed by
other parts of this code shall be exempt from the provisions of that part of this chapter pertaining to retail hardware stores.
RETAIL PAINT STORE. Any building, room, enclosure, premises, place, establishment or part of an establishment in the village, operated or conducted
for the sale or offering for sale at retail of any paints, dry colors, wall paper, varnishes, calcimine, white or red lead, raw or boiled linseed oil, turpentine,
dryer, benzine, naphtha, painters' tools, supplies and equipment; provided, however, that dealers or establishments or parts of establishments of a similar
nature specifically defined and licensed by other provisions of this code shall be exempt from the provisions of that part of this article pertaining to paint
stores.
(Ord. 73-0-229, passed 4-18-73)
§ 116.161 LICENSE REQUIRED.
No person, firm or corporation shall engage in either the business of a retail hardware store or a retail paint store without first having obtained a license
therefor. Every person licensed to engage in the business of a retail hardware store shall have the privilege of engaging in the business of a retail paint
store, within the same building, room, enclosure, premises, place, establishment or part of an establishment without the necessity of obtaining an
additional license.
(Ord. 73-0-229, passed 4-18-73)
§ 116.162 APPLICATION.
Application for the license shall be made in conformity with the general requirements of Chapter 110 of this code.
(Ord. 73-0-229, passed 4-18-73)
§ 116.163 INVESTIGATION.
Application for the license, and an investigation, shall be made in conformity with the general requirements of Chapter 110 of this code.
(Ord. 73-0-229, passed 4-18-73)
§ 116.164 FEE.
The annual fee for a retail hardware store license or a retail paint store license shall be $50.
(Ord. 73-0-229, passed 4-18-73; Am. Ord. 80-4-441, passed 4-14-80)
§ 116.165 INSPECTION.
Inspections shall be conducted and made as provided for in Chapter 110 of this code.
(Ord. 73-0-229, passed 4-18-73)
§ 116.166 VENTILATION.
No owners proprietor, manager, or superintendent of any business licensed under this article where one or more persons are employed shall cause, permit
or allow the same or any portion or apartment of any room within the same to be overcrowded or inadequate, faulty or insufficient in respect to light,
ventilation, heat and cleanliness. Fresh air shall be supplied by ventilation in accordance with the building regulations of this code. No part of the air supply
shall be taken from a cellar or basement.
(Ord. 73-0-229, passed 4-18-73)
§ 116.167 SANITARY REQUIREMENTS.
(A) Every place wherein any business licensed under this code is carried on shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. All necessary measures shall
be taken to safeguard the lives and health of all persons employed in the establishments. Adequate and convenient washing and toilet facilities shall be
provided for the employees. No person suffering from an active contagious or infectious disease shall be employed in the business. All articles kept for
sale in the establishments shall be kept free from vermin or any matter of a contagious or infectious nature.
(B) All decomposed, fetid or putrescent matter and all refuse, waste and sweepings shall be removed and disposed of at least once each day and in a
manner as not to cause a nuisance. All cleaning shall be done whenever possible after or before working hours, but if done during working hours, it
shall be done in a manner as to avoid the unnecessary raising of dust or noxious material.
(Ord. 73-0-229, passed 4-18-73)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 157/360
Ice Dealers
§ 116.180 ICE DEALER'S LICENSE; VEHICLE LICENSE.
Every ice dealer shall also pay an annual license fee of $20 for each vehicle operated in connection with the business for transportation of ice.
('68 Code, § 44.01) (Am. Ord. 80-4-431, passed 4-14-80)
§ 116.181 QUALITY OF ICE.
All ice to be sold or delivered within the village for domestic use shall be pure and healthful ice, free from matter deleterious to health. The ice, upon
chemical and bacteriological examination, shall be found free from nitrates and pathogenic bacteria and to contain not more than .009 of one part of free
ammonia and .009 of one part of albuminoid ammonia in each 100,000 parts.
('68 Code, § 44.02)
§ 116.182 SANITATION REQUIREMENTS.
Every place, plant, room, depot, station or vehicle in which ice is manufactured, stored, sold, handled or kept for the intention of being sold, either at
wholesale or retail shall be kept in a clean, healthy and sanitary condition. For the purpose of ascertaining compliance with these provisions it shall be the
duty of the Health Officer to cause the places to be examined at least once monthly.
('68 Code, § 44.03)
§ 116.183 EMPLOYEES.
Persons engaged in the manufacture or handling of ice shall provide themselves with clothes of clean, washable material which shall be used for that
purpose only. No person engaged in and about the business shall spit on the floor or side walls of any place where ice is manufactured, stored, handled or
kept for sale. No person who has any communicable or infectious disease shall work or be permitted to work in any place where ice is manufactured,
stored or handled for sale, or upon any vehicle from which ice is handled.
('68 Code, § 44.04)
§ 116.184 INSPECTION OF VEHICLES.
It shall be the duty of the Health Officer to at least once each week cause to be inspected every vehicle hauling ice, to determine if the provisions of this
subchapter are being complied with, with reference to the preservation and safety of the health of the public. The Health Officer also, at the time of the
inspection of the vehicles, shall inspect the clothing worn by persons working on the vehicles and the tools and scales used by them. The Health Officer
shall cause to be made the additional inspections as may be necessary to secure compliance with and enforcement of the health provisions of this
subchapter.
('68 Code, § 44.05)
§ 116.185 EXCEPTIONS.
(A) The provisions of this subchapter do not prohibit the selling or delivering of impure ice to be used only for packing or cooling purposes, for use in
refrigeration or cooling systems, refrigerator cars, freezing machines, rooms and other places where it will not come in contact with articles of food or
drink.
(B) Whenever any impure ice for packing or cooling purposes is sold or delivered the vendor shall warn the buyer that the ice is not for domestic use.
(C) No ice designed or intended to be sold offered for sale or delivered for domestic use shall be sold, offered for sale or delivered from any wagon or
vehicle used in the vending or distributing of ice to be used for packing and cooling purposes.
('68 Code, § 44.07)
Laundries And Dry Cleaners
§ 116.200 DEFINITIONS.
For the purpose of this subchapter the following definition shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
LAUNDRY. Any place, building or establishment which is used for the purpose of making, sorting, washing, drying, starching or ironing collars, cuffs, or
other wearing apparel, table, bed or other household linens, towels, bedding or other washable fabrics for the general public, including any private laundry
maintained or operated in connection with any hotel, restaurant or public institution, except any hospital or charitable institution where no charge is made
for laundry services. LAUNDRY does not apply to any female engaged in doing custom laundry work at her home for a regular family trade, nor to any
room located in a dwelling in which domestic laundry work is done by or for the occupants of the building exclusively.
DRY CLEANER. Any person keeping or using more than one gallon of any solvent other than water, including but not by way of limitation solvents of the
petroleum distillate type, coal tar distillate type or chlorinated hydrocarbon type, for the purpose of cleaning or renovating wearing apparel, fabrics, textiles,
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 158/360
drapes, curtains, rugs, blankets, furs, leather or other material for profit.
('68 Code, § 45.01)
§ 116.201 LAUNDRY LICENSE REQUIRED.
The annual license fee for the operation of a laundry is $50.
('68 Code, § 45.02) (Am. Ord. 73-0-227, passed 4-18-73; 80-4-432, passed - - )
§ 116.202 SANITARY CONDITIONS.
(A) Every room or place used as a laundry or for the storage of unlaundered or laundered fabrics in connection therewith shall be kept in good repair and
maintained in a clean and sanitary condition as to floors, walls, ceilings, windows, woodwork, machinery, utensils and fixtures. Every room or place
shall be kept free from rats, mice and vermin and all matters of an infectious or contagious nature.
(B) No person who has tuberculosis, acute or active venereal disease, communicable or loathsome skin disease shall work in any laundry and no owner,
proprietor, manager or person in charge of any laundry shall knowingly require, permit or suffer any person to be employed therein.
(C) No wallpaper shall be applied upon the walls or ceilings of any room used for laundry purposes.
(D) A qualified attendant or operator shall be present at all times during the operation of any laundry, subject to the provisions of this subchapter.
('68 Code, § 45.05)
§ 116.203 LIGHTING AND VENTILATION.
(A) No laundry shall be operated in any cellar, basement, or in any other room or place which is not provided with sufficient natural light by means of
windows or skylights so that on clear days during the period between one hour after sunrise and two hours before sunset illuminmeter tests show a
minimum illumination of five footcandles in all parts of the room or place not directly obstructed by machinery or other equipment. The general
arrangement of all machinery and equipment shall be such as not to unnecessarily obstruct the lighting and ventilating through the windows and
skylights.
(B) No laundry shall be operated in any room or place in which the clear height between the ceiling and the finished floor is less than ten feet, or which is
not ventilated by means of windows, skylights, air shafts, air ducts, or mechanical apparatus so that a complete change of air in all parts of the room or
place may be made at least four times each hour. In every room or place at least 1,000 cubic feet of air space shall be provided for each person
employed therein.
(C) Every room in any laundry, except rooms used for drying purposes, in which the temperature and humidity are such as to endanger the health of the
persons employed therein, shall be provided with a mechanical ventilating system approved by the health officer.
('68 Code, §§ 45.03, 45.06)
§ 116.204 FLOORS.
The floor of every laundry, except the rooms in which wearing apparel, household linens, bedding, towels or other fabrics are washed, shall be constructed
of hardwood or any impervious material. The floor of the rooms in which wearing apparel, household linens, bedding, towels or other fabrics are washed
shall be constructed of hardwood with tight joints, concrete, cement, tile or stone laid in cement, or other impervious material, and shall be water-tight and
properly drained to the public sewer. The angles where the floor and wall join shall be water-tight.
('68 Code, § 45.07)
§ 116.205 PLUMBING AND DRAINAGE.
Every laundry shall be provided with adequate sanitary plumbing and drainage facilities and the installation of all drains and plumbing fixtures shall be in
accordance with the requirements of the Building Code. Every water closet, sink or other plumbing fixture installed therein shall be of an approved type,
impermeable and thoroughly sanitary.
('68 Code, § 45.08)
§ 116.206 TOILETS AND LAVATORY FACILITIES.
(A) Every laundry shall be provided with separate water closet facilities for male and female employees and every room or compartment in which any
water closet is installed shall be provided with adequate natural ventilation by means of windows or skylights opening to the external air.
(B) Every laundry shall be provided with sufficient and suitable lavatory facilities, including approved wash bowls, wash basins or sinks supplied with hot
and cold running water, soap, clean individual towels and other equipment as the health officer may deem necessary for the health and comfort of the
persons employed therein.
('68 Code, §§ 45.09, 45.10)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 159/360
§ 116.207 SLEEPING ROOMS AND LIVING ROOMS.
(A) No person shall be permitted to sleep in any laundry, nor shall any sleeping room or living room be in direct communication with any laundry.
(B) No laundered or unlaundered fabrics belonging to the trade of any laundry shall be stored or kept in any room which is used for living purposes.
('68 Code, § 45.04)
§ 116.208 LOCKER ROOMS AND SEATS FOR EMPLOYEES.
(A) A separate room or sufficient space in a room which is entirely separate from the rooms in which wearing apparel, linen or other fabrics are washed or
dried and which can be maintained in a dry and sanitary condition shall be provided in every laundry as a cloak or locker room in which employees may
keep their wraps or outer clothing.
(B) Proper seating facilities shall be provided for each employee who, in the discharge of his duties, is required to remain stationed at any one place for an
extended period of time.
('68 Code, §§ 45.11, 45.17)
§ 116.209 HANDLING AND STORAGE OF FABRICS.
Every laundry shall provide proper facilities and equipment for the separate handling of clean and soiled fabrics; no clean or laundered fabrics shall be
allowed to come in contact with any unlaundered or soiled fabrics.
('68 Code, § 45.12)
§ 116.210 STERILIZATION; SPRINKLING; HEAT DISSIPATERS.
(A) No laundry in which wearing apparel, household linens, towels, bedding and all other fabrics are received and treated through the process of washing
shall remove the fabrics from the premises until they have been thoroughly sterilized by keeping them in the washing machine, vat or other vessel
provided for that purpose, at boiling temperature, or maintained at a temperature of 175 degrees F. for at least 20 minutes; or by subjecting them to live
steam pressure; or by keeping them in a drying house or drying chamber, in which the temperature is not less than 215 degrees F. for a period of not
less than 15 minutes; or by passing them through any ironing machine where the ironing surface is at a temperature of not less than 225 degrees F.
Silks and woolens or other fabrics which would be injured by the foregoing processes shall be treated with soap, bleach or any other standard
disinfectant solution approved by the health officer.
(B) No laundry shall sprinkle any fabrics with water or other liquid substances ejected from the mouth, or blown out of any other device communicating or
coming in contact with the mouth of a person.
(C) Every device in any laundry operated by an employee which emits or sends off excessive heat, shall be equipped with proper heat deflectors, hood
and exhaust or other apparatus that shall carry the heat from the room or place in which the device is located.
('68 Code, §§ 45.14, 45.15, 45.16)
§ 116.211 HOURS OF OPERATION.
No laundry situated in any tenement house or any building which is partially used for residence purposes shall be operated after 8:00 p.m. or before 6:00
a.m.
('68 Code, § 45.18)
§ 116.212 FUMES.
Vapors, smoke or odors emanating from any laundry shall not be permitted to become a nuisance.
('68 Code, § 45.19)
§ 116.213 INSPECTION.
It shall be the duty of the Health Officer to inspect laundries to ascertain whether the provisions of this code and the state laws relative to the keeping and
operating of laundries are being complied with, and it shall be his duty to enforce the ordinances and laws.
('68 Code, § 45.20)
§ 116.214 VEHICLES.
No cart or vehicle shall be used for the purpose of collecting or delivering laundry work unless it carries upon two sides, in plain legible letters at least 11/2
inches high, the name of the laundry where the laundry work actually is done.
('68 Code, § 45.13)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=686 160/360
§ 116.215 DRY CLEANER'S LICENSE.
The annual fee for each dry cleaning establishment is $50.
('68 Code, § 45.21) (Am. Ord. 73-0-227, passed 4-18-73; 80-4-432, passed - - )
§ 116.216 DRY CLEANING OPERATING REGULATIONS.
(A) Every dry cleaning establishment shall be equipped with an asbestos blanket of a size not less than six feet by nine feet. The blanket shall be placed
inside of dry cleaning rooms near the door thereof and in the position that it shall be accessible for use in case of fire.
(B) No dry cleaning establishment in which flammable solvents having a flash point below 140 degrees Fahrenheit (closed cup tester) are used shall be
located on any lot or plot of ground where any of the boundaries of the lot or plot of ground are within 100 feet of the nearest boundary of any lot or plot
of ground used for a church, school, hospital or theater.
(C) Vapors or odors emanating from any dry cleaning establishment shall not be permitted at any time to become a nuisance.
(D) An attendant shall be present on the immediate premises of any self-service or coin-operated dry cleaning establishment during all hours the dry
cleaning establishment is open for business, and it shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to operate any self-service coin-operated dry
cleaning establishment within the village, without there being an attendant present during all hours the dry cleaning establishment is open for business.
(E) The term "attendant" as used in this subchapter shall mean any person of adult age who is either the owner or operator of the self-service dry cleaning
establishment or an authorized employee of the owner or operator.
('68 Code, §§ 45.22-45.25)
Tattooers
§ 116.230 DEFINITION.
For the purpose of this chapter the following definition shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
TATTOO. The making of permanent marks or designs on the skin by puncturing it and inserting indelible colors. TATTOOER means one skilled in
tattooing.
('68 Code, § 51.01)
§ 116.231 LICENSE REQUIRED.
No person shall apply, make or create any tattoos upon any person or in any way engage in the business of a tattooer in the village without first obtaining a
license therefor. Application for the license shall state the name of the applicant, the place where the applicant intends to do business.
('68 Code, § 51.02)
§ 116.232 LICENSE FEE.
The annual fee for the license is $100.
('68 Code, § 51.03)
§ 116.233 HEALTH CERTIFICATE.
Prior to applying for a license to conduct the business of a tattooer, the applicant shall obtain a health certificate from a licensed physician. A health
certificate shall be issued only upon a finding of a licensed physician that the applicant is in good health and free from any communicable disease.
('68 Code, § 51.04)
§ 116.234 REQUIREMENTS FOR EMPLOYEES.
All employees of any tattooer must also be subject themselves to a physical examination by a licensed physician and it shall be unlawful to employ any
person in the business of a tattooer who does not hold a valid health certificate.
